title: we wont forget barbara windsor
story: And “forgetting” has been very much on my mind this week, with the cruelty of dementia laid bare in Thursday night’s searing ITV documentary from the always- excellent Ross Kemp.He has a personal reason for highlighting the plight of ­sufferers and carers.His EastEnders screen “mum”, Barbara Windsor, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s six years ago and her condition has rapidly deteriorated since lockdown.The -year-old film and TV legend is now so badly affected she may soon have to go into a care home. That is something her devoted husband, Scott Mitchell, has been dreading.The couple married in  with some cynics snfily declaring it would never last, mainly because of the -year age gap, but Scott proved them all completely wrong.He adores his we and has put his le on hold, and his physical and mental health at risk, to take care of his Barbara.Scott has also helped to raise funds and awareness for dementia charities, even taking part in the London Marathon with a group of Barbara’s friends from EastEnders.It has been deeply sad to see how this disease has ravaged one of the most delightful women in showbiz.I always adored interviewing Barbara. She was sunny, funny, full of fascinating stories and always interested in everyone and everything.She would have a laugh with the crew, a cheery chat with our production team and was exactly the same whether the cameras were rolling or not.I know a lot of famous actors and entertainers who are grumpy gits until the red light goes on. Barbara was never like that. She is a consummate professional, but also a delightfully warm human being.I remember seeing her at an event in London, where she was swamped by photographers and members of the public. She’s so tiny I couldn’t actually see her in that large sea of people, but what I did observe was how everyone came away with an autograph or a selfie.Barbara is old school. She always said she owes her fame to the public and that they deserved a smile, a cheery wave and a quick photograph.That’s why she is so adored and why we are so very upset she is having to go through this anguish. Scott says her speech is growing worse and she now struggles to find the words to express herself.She ends up sitting shaking her head in sadness and frustration. Barbara is also getting up two or three times a night, becoming unsteady on her feet and falling over. Scott is worried sick that she will suffer a really serious injury.Sometimes Barbara looks at old photos of herself and asks, “Who is she ” and increasingly she doesn’t recognise Scott, which cuts him to his very heart and soul.This disease is so brutal, because it chips away at the sufferer, steals their memories and erodes what makes them unique. You gradually lose the person you love and have to mourn them while they are still alive. That’s why the work both Scott and Barbara have been doing is so vital.When she bravely told us she was ill two years ago, the Alzheimer’s Society saw visits to its website double and one-off donations to the charity rose by  per cent.She made a plea to the PM to help carers and sufferers, and to increase funding, and Barbara was one of the few people that made Boris Johnson stop waffling and actually listen.Dementia is a second epidemic within this pandemic, which is why we need more documentaries like the ones from Ross.There are , sufferers that we know about in the UK, and with us all living longer that number will carry on increasing.Relatives caring for those blighted by the disease can often feel alone and helpless. GPs and the NHS do their best, but it can be a lottery as to what expert care is available.As we have seen during this crisis, care home workers are an extraordinary group of people who treat their frail and elderly patients like a second family, but no one really wants to put a beloved parent or partner into a nursing home.There comes a time, however, when there is no other choice. Scott is now facing that prospect and it is tearing him apart. I also spoke this week to the musician Naughty Boy, whose mum Zahida suffers from dementia.He is a devoted son and lives with his mum to take care of her. Naughty Boy is backing Dementia UK’s Lives On Hold campaign, which focuses on carers and how draining it is for them, especially since lockdown. He wants to stress that there is help out there. I was touched at how he makes sure there is at least one thing every day for his mum to look forward to, to give her joy.He tries to see some light in the darkness and it’s also something Scott has always tried to do. He has to be Barbara’s memory and keep a hold of the love they have for one another.Eventhey have to be parted so she can go into a home, nothing can take that love away from him or anyone  going through the same sad experience.IF you are going to quote Game Of Thrones, then for the love of God at least get it right.Tone deaf Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab dismissed those who support the Black Lives Matter campaign by taking a knee, as seeming to “get the idea from Game Of Thrones”.This was not only hugely insulting, but Raab didn’t even bother to get the phraseology right. In Game Of Thrones, the characters are willing to die before they would BEND the knee in front of despots and royalty.In the real world it’s about expressing solidarity against racial inequality.Raab believes the heartfelt gesture is a “symbol of subjugation and subordination” and he would only do so for the Queen and his we. Those who take the knee, including footballers at theof the Premier League this week, and many protesters here and in the US, were astounded by his crass remarks.Following such wide­spread incredulity and anger, Raab has been furiously back-tracking. I do hope his Twitter clarication is genuine and not just another Government damage-limitation tactic.If this really was an episode of Game Of Thrones, he would have had his a*** handed to him by my favourite character, Sandor Clegane, known as The Hound.After that encounter, I guarantee he would never again be able to bend any part of his anatomy.HOLLYOAKS actor Adam Rickitt is an astonishingly candid and brave man. He not only spoke about his mental health at a time when it was considered career-destroying, but has talked frankly this week about being infertile.Adam suffers from an auto-immune disease that has made it impossible for him to ever father children. The -year-old has ankylosing spondylitis, which has had a devastating effect on his sperm count.While other men might have felt embarrassed about it, Adam has been refreshingly honest. He revealed the doctor told him most men have three million sperm, but he only had two. Not two million but TWO.He and his we Katy Fawcett, a top correspondent with Good Morning Britain, are very happy with their three dogs. Adam has been equally upfront about his mental health and suicidal thoughts. Since meeting Katy in  his le has turned around and, alongside acting jobs, he’s running a craft beer bar and shop. The couple call it their “baby”.They adore each other and are lucky to feel complete without kids.GWYNETH PALTROW’S latest attention- seeking wheeze is to bring out a candle that “smells of her orgasm”. This is a follow-up to last year’s model that bore the catchy title, “This candle smells of my vagina”.Not sure about you, but I have no wish to have my living room reeking of Gywn or anything to do with her sex le.I also cannot begin to imagine the sheer buttock-clenching embarrassment suffered by her two teenage kids.I think what her candles really smell of are pure unadulterated bulls**t.THE Oscars and Baftas have been delayed for a few months due to Covid-, so this could be a good time for the film industry to have a rethink about the whole business of award shows.Instead of a seemingly never-ending run of ceremonies, perhaps there should be a cull. In the US they could keep the Oscars for films, the Emmys for TV and the Tonys for theatre, and here the Baftas, NTAs and Oliviers.Then each event would be special, rather than a seemingly endless parade of bored-looking stars like Renee Zellweger, above, done up to the nines and wishing they were at home.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: children homework plan school
story: The -year-olds were asked to choose their favourite hymn and style of coffin.They even had to choose what flowers would be appropriate for their memorial and draw up a guest list. title: end virtue signalling serious conversation
story: Mirza, recently appointed to run the Government’s new Racial Inequality Review, has been described as a “racial gatekeeper”, among other things Patel has been accused of “gaslighting” by Labour MPs after talking about her own experiences of racism.I feel it especially because I have something in common with Patel and Mirza: We are ethnic minority women who do not accept the standard leftist view of racism.In  I spoke out about the state of our education system at the Conservative Party Conference, criticising the “culture of excuses”.For some, this was the worst thing I could do. No matter that I am not, nor have ever been, a member of the Conservative Party.I would never be forgiven by some people, who just couldn’t understand why an ethnic minority person would have sympathy for Conservative policies. At best we’ve been hoodwinked at worst we must just be plain evil.It often feels like we are not allowed to think for ourselves, outside of the orthodoxies set down by left-wing political groupthink.In the days of fighting to set up my school, and in our first few years of establishing ourselves, I received racist emails and threats of violence — from the Left.There were protests outside my school and abuse was shouted in my face from militant union members opposed to free schools.My detractors tried hard to discredit me in ways that made sense to them.There was even a running Wikipedia battle over my heritage, lasting for years.It was regularly edited to state that I was of Indian descent, while some people claimed my ancestry to be Indian Ugandan, and thereforethat I must hate black people.It was absurd, and I didn’t know from one day to the next what race my Wikipedia page would say I was.While it seems a bizarre thing to fight over, some opponents clearly believed that my criticisms of the education system and my support for free schools could be discountedI wasn’t black.My experience ten years ago is why today I have the greatest sympathy for Conservative MPs such as Priti Patel and Kemi Badenoch. Heaven knows what actual Tory MPs from ethnic minorities must have to endure.Mirza has been working with the Conservative Party for many years and her simple appointment to this role has enraged her detractors. For them, a “good” ethnic minority is one who always toes the leftist line.So play around with my Wikipedia page, make me Indian with a couple of keyboard strokes, and suddenly not only have they wiped my mother out of existence, but my words don’t really matter any more. This accusation of “not being black enough” raised its ugly head when Priti Patel was accused of distracting from the racism facing black people by highlighting her own experiences — assomehow her struggles were worth less because she is of Indian heritage .That being called a “P**i” as a young girl wouldn’t have had the same crushing, hurtful impact as any other racial slur. Similarly, Munira Mirza has been accused of not being able to understand the experiences of black people because she is of Pakistani origin.The recent protests inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement should have provoked serious conversations about the meaning and impact of race we all need to explore the nature of racism and what to do about it.But it is clear to me, from the black boxes on Instagram to the meaningless supportive BLM statements on corporate websites, that few people are interested in examining race in our own society.Most people want an easy fix, a stamp of approval that will allow them to be branded a non-racist so that they can go back to their normal lives, satisfied that they are a good person .This is not even remotely helpful to anyone, it’s simple box ticking but the desire to signal “anti-racism” instead of just not being a racist is so prevalent that at times I wonder whether human beings have the capacity to distinguish between the two: The signal and the reality.This tick-box race culture goes hand in hand with the oppression Olympics. Hierarchies of race are the easy bingo card that allows ethnic people to be ticked off on a sheet.Chinese  Sorry, only two oppression points for you. Black  Wow, that’s ten points! You go straight to the top!This is why,you are merely interested in appearing to be non-racist, rather than actually being a non-racist, you will buy into the idea of this totem pole of oppression.You will ignore that race and class are so much more complex than this.My father was of Indian heritage, but he came from a much poorer environment than my black mother and grew up without any shoes.Le is more complicated than the tick-box culture allows, butyour only interest in race is to do enough to signal to everyone that you aren’t a racist, then you will promote that hierarchy enthusiastically, because it is the perfect prop for your non-racist dissimulation. It doesn’t require any thought or effort.The reality of being anti-racist requires years of reading and discussion, befriending a iety of black people, including ones who think dferently from you politicallyand really coming to terms with one’s own uncomfortable feelings around race. Signalling requires a black box on Instagram and instantly everyone approves of you. You can see why most people choose the simpler option.In fact, spending a letime helping black boys realise their potential, something Black Lives Matter should approve of, instead of earning me adoration as a black box on Instagram does, has given me many enemies.My -plus years of improving young people’s lives is meaningless next to the superficial letters of support for BLM, because making a useful dference to people’s lives is less important than being seen to do so. It is a wonder why anyone ever does anything truly good at all.But there is one way of being anti-racist in a very simple and real way that takes no time at all.Allow Priti Patel, Kemi Badenoch and Munira Mirza the right that so many white people enjoy and take for granted: The right to think for themselves.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Musical writing legend Andrew Lloyd Webber is spearheading efforts to bring in high-tech fixes so " rel"noreferrer noopener"venues can open their doors again quickly.⚠️ Read our coronavirus meaning many more pubs could soon open - but for the moment punters still need to queue sensibly and take their pints to go.Britain has endured  weeks of restrictions and social distancing to stem the spread of coronavirus.And now, as rules are gradually relaxed, there is more light at the end of the tunnel.Within the next fortnight announcements are expected to allow hotels and restaurants to reopen next month.Brits desperately missing catching up with pals at the pub could soon be back at the bar or ordering through an app to keep safe.It comes as:To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Schools are set to be given new guidance which would allow children toto the classroom in numbers of up to  from September.And families who have been diligently keeping apart since the lockdown was announced could soon have overnight stays with their loved ones.At the moment, overnight stays are not allowed, and even being inside another household which you are not bubbled up with is not permitted.And as the summer holiday months approach, ministers are also said to be fine tuning negotiations to set up air bridges with up ten countries, to allow Brits to go abroad without facing severe quarantine restrictions.Airports are gradually opening up again, signalling theof non essential travel - with London City Airport reopening on Sunday after being closed to commercial flights for nearly three months.More than two million vulnerable people were ordered to shield and stay inside to protect them from the killer bug, but they will soon be allowed to go shopping and enjoy leisure activities.Britains high streets were opened back up last week and people were seen eagerly flooding to the shops - as the PM works to get the economy back up and running once more.Scientists have said they are totally comfortable with the two-metre social distancing rule being reduced - but onlypeople sit side by side and wear face coverings as much as possible.The UKs coronavirus death toll hit , yesterday - title: first concert coronavirus lockdown bands cars
story: Three local bands played to the -strong sold-out crowd at Hampshires Royal Victoria Country Park yesterday giving live music fans desperate for a dance their first glimpse into the scenes new normal.Pubs and clubs were forced to close their doors from March to battle the virus and almost all summer festivals are cancelled so venues are thinking up and rolling-out plans to put on socially-distanced drive-in shows.Organiser George Rashbrook, of SoundLevel Events, said: It went really really well tonight, it could not have gone better, everything from the audience to the weather to the music, its been absolutely perfect.Revellers rushed to bag their ticket as the events -car limit sold out in a day, costing £ per car with up to five people per vehicle. Fans parked a safe distance from others and many had their own alcohol and picnics to enjoy with the music while some perched on their car roofs for a better view. Local artists Sean McGowan, Me And The Moon, and Bash! all took to the stage. The evening finished with Sean McGowan getting everyone to toot their horns and flash their lights for a bit of fun. Tom Chance, , went with we Aeysha, , and their four-month-old baby Sofia. Tom, from Bassett, Southampton, said: We fancied a night out and have been looking forward to getting out the house, and who knows, this maybe the future of music venues going forward. It’s a fantastic idea, with social distancing enforced. We do go to gigs and this is Sophia’s first one and wasn’t quite how we imagined it would work out, but we are here and its great.The event was organised in about four weeks and licensed by the council, who bought into it straight away and loved it while Hampshire Constabulary had no issues with it going ahead. Mr Rashbrook, who has worked with the council for past gigs at its facilities, added: Everyone has been really supportive. We had people either in their cars, or just to the left of their cars so everyone was socially distant with their own little safe bubble.He said he cant wait for his next drive-in gig on July  and hopes the council would re-do its risk assessment to allow for a bigger crowd because there is certainly the demand for it.The live music economy has been shattered by coronavirus and could be one of the last industries to ever get back to giving the experience fans are used to because social distancing can be impossible to enforce in venues.And with guidelines suggesting the virus is less-easily transmitted outdoors drive-in gigs more musicians could take their music outside as the new normal.The Sun revealed earlier this week that events giant Live Nation would unveil a series of festival-style events across Britain with socially distanced drive-in gigs.Computer-generated graphics revealed how cars will be ushered into designated spots on the site, with food and drink facilities also laid on to complete the concert experience.Performances from acts including The Streets, Spandau Ballet’s Tony Hadley, The Lightning Seeds, Cream, jazz singer Beverley Knight, DJ Sigala and classical singer Russell Watson were unveiled.A host of pop acts including Rita Ora, Little Mix and Jess Glynne are also understood to be in discussions to join the summer line-up.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beauty salons offer botox lockdown
story: Beauty salons are considered non-essential and were closed in March to limit the spread of coronavirus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut some have reopened, Party Parliamentary Group for Beauty, Aesthetics and Wellbeing warn it poses a “serious health and safety risk”.They have now written to business minister Kwasi Kwarteng urging him to shut them down loophole in the guidance that medical services can reopen, while the Government has made clear that the beauty industry should remain closed at this stage.“Carrying out aesthetics treatments in lockdown clearly goes against Government advice and this guidance must urgently be updated to end all ambiguity.“This not only presents a serious public health and safety risk to practitioners and customers, but also undermines responsible operators who rightfully remain closed, and risks harming consumer confidence as the beauty industry looks to reopen.”The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy says it is for Trading Standards to enforce the rules.Botox is a prescription-only medicine, which can only be prescribed after an in-person medical check.Labour MP Carolyn Harris, who co-chairs the group, told The Sun: “There is a very clear dference between a medical need and an aesthetic desire.“Treatments that are not essential to improving health should not be undertaken at title: when eid al adha 2020 uk date how celebrate
story: It is the celebration of Ibrahimagreeing to sacrice his son Ishmael under Allah Gods orders, which was then interrupted by God.Eid ul-Adha is celebrated on the th day of Dhū al-Hijjah, the twelfth and final month of the Islamic calendar.It lasts for four days. The first day of Eid ul-Adha marks the end of the annual Hajj pilgrimage to Makkah.Due to Islam traditionally using the lunar calendar the date does sht and its not officially on until theres a clear enough sky showing the crescent of a new moon.This means that there is also a day-long iation between countries depending on where they are in the world.In the UK Eid ul-Adha  will begin on the evening of Thursday, July  and end on the evening of Monday, August .Eid usually starts with Muslims going to the Mosque for prayers in new finery.As the name would suggest, over the weekend there is usually the sacrice of a sheep, goat, camel or cow. The act is called Qurbani.In the period around Eid al-Adha, many Muslims travel to Mecca and the surrounding area in Saudi Arabia to perform the Hajj pilgrimage, which is one of the five pillars of Islam.It is a public holiday in traditionally or majority Muslim countries like Indonesia or the United Arab Emirates, but it isnt in more historically Christian countries like the UK.In the UK the animal is slaughtered in a slaughterhouse, but in other countries it is often done as part of a public ritual.It is a time that is spent visiting family and friends, usually involving a big meal and some partying. Kids often get presents too.The meat is shared equally between family, friends and the poor and unlike Eid ul-Fitr, the meals made are predominantly savory. It is a time when they visit family and friends. Muslims will also give money to charity so that poor people can celebrate too.There are two Eids, which makes things a bit confusing for those not brought up in Islam.Firstly, Eid means feast, so theyre both family gatherings and a good excuse for a party.Eid al-Fitr is celebrated at the end of Ramadan, this year in early June, to celebrate the end of fasting.Eid al-Fitr is often referred to as the sweet feast as Muslims will tend to put a greater emphasis on puddings and all the nice little treats they werent allowed during fasting.Eid al-Adha is the one thats coming up at the end of July and is the holier of the two feasts.It coincides with the end of the Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, and is around two months after Eid al-Fitr.It is deemed the savoury or salty feast as there is a surplus of meat from the sacrice of the cattle that gets shared around everyone.Eid al-Adha sees the sacrices made as a symbolic act to mimic the near-sacrice of Ibrahimwho agreed to sacrice his son Ishmael when Allah God asked him to in repeated dreams.Ibrahim leads Ishmael to Mount Arafat, tied up his son and stuck a blindfold on so he wouldnt have to watch him suffer. The story goes that Allah replaced Ibrahim with a sheep as Ibrahim blindly flung the kne at his son. Other iations include an angel stepping in at the last moment and giving him a sheep or goat.This is the same story from the Old Testament of Abraham and Isaac.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china coronavirus new data
story: Data published by Chinese officials show . million cases of Influenza were recorded in December, which is up from , in the same month the year before.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThis massive jump in cases of the flu, whose feverous symptoms are similar to that of coronavirus, could be part of the undetected spread of the virus.Chinas accuracy in terms of their COVID- data has been repeatedly questioned- with analysts now believing that the infection number was much higher than first thought.This may mean that the official death toll is higher than official data shows.One study published this week claimed Chinas real coronavirus death toll could be  times higher than figures given by Beijing, with US researchers estimating , people had died in Wuhan alone by  March.Suspicions have mounted - especially since there has been a spike in cases in the capital this week, despite going nearly two months without a single infection.According to Taiwanese consultancy group Sindolnsider, Chinese health officials stopped providing flu updates on  December, just four days before the first COVID- cases were reported.The report said: We have reasons to believe that the uncharacteristic explosion of flu cases in December may be due to the undetected spread of the coronavirus.We estimate that tens of thousands of people could have been infected with Covid- by the end of December.Another study released this week has looked at the activity of crematoriums in Wuhan - concluding that China has concealed the true size of its pandemic.It estimated that Wuhan was burning up to , bodies a day by mid February - when Chinas death toll was only at .By  March, Chinas official toll was , - however this study suggests that the number was closer to ,.Beijing states that China has had , deaths from coronavirus - which is less than a tenth of the UKs death toll.Alongside the reports and studies, world leaders have also questioned Chinas data accuracy.President Trump called out the World Health Organisationin April over not forcing China to reveal more data.However,WHO investigators said they were happy that Beijing was telling the truth about what was happening.There has now been a sudden surge in Chinas COVID- cases despite having two months of no cases - You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis week has seen a flurry of lockdown changes in Scotland and Wales - while England continues to march forward too. It can all get a bit confusing. After all, you can meet friends and family in all three nations but the rules are dferent for each one. England is ahead of the curve on opening non-essential shops, letting people in Bristol pop to Primark a week earlier than in Cardf. But Wales is ahead when it comes to giving some kind of signal for when its residents can go on holiday or get a haircut. So after this weekaposs changes, what is the situation in Scotland, Wales and England and how do the three sets of rules dfer  Weaposve looked at  key areas and how they affect you.   SCOTLAND: Groups of up to eight people from a maximum of three households may meet outside, as long as people in dferent households stay two metres apart. Gatherings of more than two people from dferent households are banned indoors - unless you form a aposbubbleapos between two households, at least one of which must be a single-adult household. WALES: Groups of an unspecied number of people from a maximum of two households may meet outside, as long as people in dferent households stay two metres apart. Gatherings of more than two people from dferent households are banned indoors and there is no bubble system. ENGLAND: Groups of up to six people from unlimited households may meet outside, as long as people in dferent households stay two metres apart. Gatherings of more than two people from dferent households are banned indoors - unless you form a aposbubbleapos between two households, at least one of which must be a single-adult household.   SCOTLAND: Non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen from June  - but must have street access, so shops in shopping centres are not allowed. WALES: Non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen from June  - with no ban on shops inside shopping centres. ENGLAND: Non-essential shops were allowed to reopen from June  - with no ban on shops inside shopping centres. For all three nations, strict social distancing must be in place.  SCOTLAND: People should not travel more than five miles away from their home for leisure or recreation - for now. This rule will be dropped when Scotland enters the next phase of easing lockdown. WALES: People should not travel more than five miles away from their home for leisure or recreation - for now. But the five-mile rule is likely to be dropped on July , and tourist bookings for aposself-containedapos accommodation - static caravans, cottages and some hotels - can probably be taken from July . ENGLAND: People can already travel an unlimited distance from their home for leisure or recreation, but are not allowed to stay away from their home overnight. Hospitality firms can start reopening from July  at the earliest, but there is no firm date and itaposs not confirmed where holiday sites will come in the priority order. The overnight stays ban is likely to be scrapped before then. Hairdressers and barber shops    SCOTLAND: There is no date for reopening hair and beauty salons, and it wonapost happen before July . Despite the best efforts of teachers and support staff, lockdown has had a huge impact on the education of millions of children and young people. This has put a huge strain on parents across Britain and it could well have a devastating impact on the wellbeing of many children. I do not underestimate how dficult it is to reopen schools safely in the current climate. But Prime Minister has simply not risen to the challenge. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson is reportedly preparing to signicantly relax the coronavirus lockdown and reopen the economy over the coming fortnight. It comes after the UKaposs coronavirus alert level was reduced today for the first time since the start of the pandemic. A Government source told the Daily Mail that its scientic advisers are now totally comfortable with relaxing the two-metre rule, after the threat from Covid- was downgraded from level four to three. It is understood that scientists have given their approval to reduce the distance people need to stay apart to one metre,other precautions are taken. This is seen as crucialpubs and hospitality venues are able to reopen, with reports of social distancing patrols and apps being used to order drinks being part of measures to help them get up and running. This is likely to include more widespread use of face masks, screens and making sure buildings are ventilated. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here The measure is one of several that the PM is expected to announce over the next two weeks in an attempt to revive the economy andto a new normal. Earlier today, Mr Johnson said he wanted all children in England toto school on a five-dayss-a-week basis in September. Meanwhile, ministers are said to be negotiating holiday air bridges with  other countries to allow travel overseas, while the Welsh Government has announced it wants to restart tourism next month. A Whitehall source has also told the paper that two families could be allowed to visit each other at home as part of expanded support bubbles. Health officials are also preparing to write to more than two million people who are currently shielding due to health conditions, telling them they can soon venture outside to shop and enjoy leisure activities. It comes after the UKaposs four Chief Medical Officers for the four nations of the UK agreed to reduce the coronavirus threat level as the number of new infections continues to slow. The downgrading - recommended by the Joint Biosecurity Centre- means the Covid- epidemic is in general circulation, but transmission is no longer high or rising exponentially. However, advisers have warned that localised outbreaks of Covid- are still likely to occur.  Health Secretary Matt Hancock boasted it is a big moment for the country, and a real testament to the British people’s determination to beat this virus. Earlier today, the Prime Minister dropped his strongest hint yet that the two-metre social distancing rule could be dropped. On a visit to Bovingdon Primary School in Hertfordshire on Friday, he told the public to watch this space when askedthe measure could be relaxed to help schools in Englandin autumn. A Downing Street team is already running an urgent review of the two-metre rule, which is expected to conclude next week. The review could see the recommended distance between people in shops and outdoor spaces cut to a level seen in other European countries. It comes after warnings from the hospitality industry and MPs that thousands of pubs, restaurants and cafes would go bustforced to re-open while the two-metre rule is still in place.

story: NewsTory activist suspended after saying Labour MP Naz Shah should go back to PakistanTheodora Dickinson, a Tory activist and former Vote Leave campaigner, has been suspended after making comments on Twitter about Labour shadow minister Naz Shah which have been branded "blatant racism"ShareCommentsBySam BlewettAnna MacSwan:,  JUN NewsA former Vote Leave campaigner made the comments about Labour shadow minister Naz Shah" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A Conservative activist has been suspended after telling a Muslim Labour MP to go back to Pakistan.The party has launched an investigation after Theodora Dickinson, who formerly worked for Vote Leave, made the comments about shadow minister Naz Shah on social media. In a now-deleted tweet, she responded to a post in which the Bradford West MP discusses her experience of poverty, sayingNaz Shah hates this country so much why doesnapost she go back to Pakistan ! Ms Shah, who was born in Bradford, said: Over the last few weeks BAMEcommunities have been coming to terms with the racism they have faced over the years. In  to be told to go back to Pakistan, highlights the level of racism that still exists in some quarters of society.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email The Muslim Council of Britain, which has long criticised the Toriesapos handling of Islamophobia, described the tweet as blatant racism. The organisationaposs secretary general Harun Khan has also accused Ms Dickinson of previously sharing an Islamophobic conspiracy theory after the Christchurch terrorist attack in New Zealand. Will this latest blatant racism elicit action  he said.  The party must reflect and consider why it chooses to ignore widespread concerns about its institutional Islamophobia -a truly independent inquiry is not enacted with its recommendations implemented, there will be a drip-feed of these stories for a long time to come. Meanwhile Baroness Sayeeda Warsi said the episode was symptomatic of the partyaposs shambolic revolving door system of dealing with racism. Lady Warsi, a former Conservative Party chair, tweeted: The Tory suspended this week for saying Muslim MP should go back to Pakistan was someone I raised concerns about over a year ago - I was told then she was suspended. This is the @Conservatives shambolic revolving door system of dealing with racism. Ms Dickinson, who describes herself as a political communications and social media consultant, later apologised for her tweet.

title: uk wrong right during pandemic
story: NewsAll UK has got wrong - and right - during pandemic ranked in our Covid AuditWe rate the governments response to the coronavirus crisis in an audit taking the Mirrors microscope to what they got right - and what they got wrongShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editorGraham HiscottHead of BusinessJason Beattie:,  JUN NewsWe have rated Prime Ministers Boris Johnsons governments response to the Covid- crisis " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe are three months into the Covid crisis and the Government is facing mounting questions about its handling of the epidemic. Boris Johnson says he is very proud of his administration’s response despite the UK having one of the highest death tolls in the world, problems with test and trace, and the confusion on getting children back to school. In our second major audit, our Health Editor, Business Editor and Head of Politics give their verdicts and look at what the Government has got right and what it got wrong. Here are our verdicts... Lockdown What they got right: A consensus has now emerged thatthe Government had locked down earlier, it would have saved tens of thousands of lives.However, when lockdown came it was better managed than some European countries. Allowing an hour of daily exercise contributed to high levels of public compliance. What they got wrong: The UK’s top infection modeller, Prof Neil Ferguson told MPs half of all deaths could have been avoidedlockdown was called just a week earlier.With the Office for National Statistics now putting Covid--linked deaths at more than ,, that was a staggering conclusion. The decision now facing ministers is how soon and how much to ease lockdown. The ability of the economy to reopen depends on how strictly businesses are required to stick to social distancing rules and, for instance, whether they may be eased from keeping m apart to .m or m. Verdict: That Britain was one of the last countries in Europe to introduce lockdown will be a defining decision of the pandemic. PPE What they got right: Problems accessing suitable personal protective equipment have eased in recent weeks. Supply networks have been established but many healthcare organisations have been forced to source their own stocks.Problems remain, particularly in dentistry, due to the cost of PPE. What they got wrong: An independent committee advising on pandemic risk had recommended in  that PPE be stockpiled for the NHS – but it was ignored.The National Audit Office found central stocks supplied only % of gowns, % of goggles and % of aprons that models said would be needed under a “reasonable worst-case scenario”. Office for National Statistics data shows infection rates in hospitals and care homes are still stubbornly high compared to rates in the general public. Verdict: The NAO report makes a mockery of claims by Health Secretary Matt Hancock that Britain had enough PPE but was just struggling to get it to the right places. Care homes What they got right: The Government pledged £.billion to help local authorities respond to coronavirus. The bulk of the money was intended to help social care services.What they got wrong: Years of failed efforts to integrate NHS and social care hampered the response. Unlike the NHS, there was a lack of centralised data on infection rates ripping through many of the UK’s , independent care home providers early on. The NAO found , hospital patients were discharged to care homes without even being tested at the height of the outbreak. This came while Health Secretary Matt Hancock claimed to have “thrown a protective ring” around care homes. Just % of PPE was sent to homes from central stocks compared with what modelling had said was needed. Care homes have lost thousands to Covid-, leaving many independent providers on the verge of going bust. Verdict: Reform of a system on the brink is vital but residents and families fear things will get worse before they get better. Furlough What they got right: The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme launched by Chancellor Rishi Sunak was the Government’s biggest weapon in the face of the crisis.More than nine million workers are having % of wages covered by the state. The scheme prevented massive job losses but at huge cost to the taxpayer – almost £billlion and growing. What they got wrong: Early issues included the cut-off for when new employees were eligible, which was extended. There have also been concerns about possible fraudulent applications.But the biggest concern is the months ahead. The scheme will be wound down from the end of July, when employers will be expected to pay gradually more – sparking fears of staff being axed. The scheme ends on October , which could result in even more redundancies in sectors still suffering. Verdict: The scheme prevented a tsunami of job losses. But wave upon wave of redundancies have already been announced and expect more jobs misery to come. Quarantine What they got right: It’s hard to know at this stage, given the onslaught of criticism. Most people arriving in the UK from June  have had to self-isolate for  days.Home Secretary Priti Patel claimed scientic advice showed introducing the measure sooner would have made “little dference” to the spread of Covid- but that the UK was now “more vulnerable” to infections coming from abroad. What they got wrong: Convincing the public, airlines and other businesses it was the right thing to do.It is claimed the quarantining rule is costing the economy £million a week. Britain’s three biggest airlines – British Airways, easyJet and Ryanair – are seeking an urgent judicial review, saying the policy is having a devastating effect. The Government is due to look at the policy again on June . Verdict: Any scientic evidence that quarantining was the right move has been eclipsed by the shambolic way in which the scheme has been introduced. BAME deaths What they got right: Public Health England was commissioned to look at the impact of Covid on minority groups. It found Black, Asian and minority ethnic people are more likely to die.People of Bangladeshi ethnicity had around twice the risk of white British. People of Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, other Asian, Caribbean and black ethnicity had between % and % higher risk. A separate report by the Office for National Statistics found people in poorer areas were more likely to die from Covid. The most deprived areas of England and Wales have . deaths per , people, compared with . in affluent areas. What they got wrong: Boris Johnson has appointed Minister for Equalities Kemi Badenoch to review the impact of Covid on the Black and Asian communities.But the Government has not said when it will be published or what action it will take to protect those most at risk, including BAME workers in the health and care sectors. Verdict: Not enough action to protect minorities and poorest. Test and Trace What they got right: Contact tracing was rolled out suspiciously early amid a political storm around the lockdown breach by aide Dominic Cummings.Despite this speed, the UK is already carrying out more tests than in most comparable countries due to our high infection rates. NHS Test and Trace has yet to reveal how quickly people are being traced, which is key to preventing a second wave. What they got wrong: Data from the first fortnight shows a quarter who order a test cannot be contacted or refuse to give friends’ details.Contact tracers were meant to be helped by an NHS app, promised by mid-May but scrapped after a troubled trial.The Health Secretary will now look at an app by Apple and Google which will not allow the NHS to access data to identy local outbreaks. Any app will be ready by winter at best.The statistics watchdog also rapped “inadequate” testing figures. Verdict: The performance of the call-centre contact tracing system is improving but time will tellit is enough. Schools What they got right: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has finally announced a £billion package to help pupils in England catch up.This will cover tutoring for disadvantaged kids and one-to-one or group tuition for primary and secondary pupils. It works out as just six hours of extra teaching per child, despite many having lost six months of school time. Nor does it include help for sixth-formers. What they got wrong: There is still no national plan for getting pupils in England back to school. The Government had wanted all primaries to reopen for all kids before the summer holidays.They had to ditch this goal when teachers and unions pointed out it was impractical under social distancing rules. It is not certain that all schools will be able to reopen in Septemberthey have to split pupils into -strong “bubbles”. This may require more staff and using other public buildings as temporary classes. Verdict: The absence of a clear plan has left parents and teachers confused.Vulnerable What they got right: Councils got support to provide accommodation for people living on the streets. After pressure from opposition MPs, the Home Office found £milllion to support victims of domestic abuse during the pandemic. But the Government has yet to commit to long-term funding to help rough sleepers. Labour says just £.m of the £m to help domestic abuse victims has reached the front line. What they got wrong: It took a campaign by Man Utd star Marcus Rashford for the Government to agree to extend free school meals for the summer holiday. The PM also U-turned on measures forcing overseas NHS workers to pay for their own treatment. New claimants for Universal Credit are still having to wait five weeks for the first payment and demand for foodbank support has risen by % since the lockdown.Verdict: The Government has a blind spot when it comes to helping the disadvantaged.Overall What they got right: When the outbreak struck, the Government basked in a lot of public goodwill as the country came together. The rapid building of the Nightingale hospitals was a huge collective effort.Chancellor Rishi Sunak also won plaudits for the smooth rollout of the furlough scheme. There was also praise for the clear communications from the Government which led to millions of people abiding by the message to “stay at home, protect the NHS and save lives”.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Labour inquest is grim read but Starmer gives reasons for optimismTo win the next election Labour needs a swing greater than Tony Blair managed in  but Keir Starmers excellent start gives reasons to be optimistic and must be built on with attractive policy agendaShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JUN NewsopinionKeir Starmer has taken the fight to Boris Johnson " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe official inquest into Labour’s general election defeat last year makes grim reading for the party. A combination of Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership, toxic infighting and an unpopular stance on Brexit all contributed to Labour’s worst showing for more than  years. The review also notes victory at the next election is far from guaranteed, saying hoping Brexit will go away and having a new leader will not automatically reverse fortunes. To win a majority next time needs a swing greater than Tony Blair managed in . It requires winning back seats from the SNP in Scotland and those lost to the Tories in the Midlands and north of England. While Labour stacked up votes in big cities, it has lost voters in towns and coastal resorts. No wonder the report concludes there is a mountain to climb. But there are also reasons for optimism. Keir Starmer has made an excellent start as leader. He has taken the fight to Boris Johnson, appointed a talented Shadow Cabinet and started to heal some of the party’s isions. Labour needs to build on this early success by developing an attractive policy agenda. Wright fright Football legend Ian Wright has taken the bold step of sharing the racist abuse he receives on social media. A lot of it came after he spoke in support of Black Lives Matter and is sickening reading.  Nobody would tolerate this vile languagethey heard it in a shop or a pub. Yet social media giants still refuse to act when racist messages are posted on their s. It is time these tech firms took responsibility for what they publish. Andthey refuse to act the law should be changed to force them to clean up these sewers of hatred and malice. Queen of shops

title: well done matt hancock you
story: NewsopinionWell done, Matt Hancock. You could not have cocked things up any moreyoud triedMore than one political career will be killed off by the pandemic, but that of the Health Secretary is closest to , freshly-dug gravesShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUN Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor me, Matt Hancock announced to the nation yesterday, what matters is what works. His portentous, I-am-serious-me statement did not add so I can f*** it right up at the end, but it might as well have done.As Britain emerges from lockdown and , excess deaths, mostly due to the virus getting a bit tired rather than any brilliance on the governmentaposs part, blame is being bundled up in preparation for the Prime Ministerial reshuffle which will send it as far away as possible.One of the recipients will be the Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, whose response to a health pandemic has been to destroy the health and social care of as many people as possible, with a level of incompetence that is close to brilliantly awful.  At the start of April, Apple and Google joined forces to use smartphones to trace coronavirus outbreaks. Within days, journalists were briefed the NHS was developing its own version, available in weeks, to ease lockdown. The fact UK local authorities had public health officials trained in tracing disease outbreaks was barely mentioned.On April , Halfcocked announced: Today I wanted to outline the next step: a new NHS app for contact tracing [...] We’re already testing this app and as we do this we’re working closely with the world’s leading tech companies and renowned experts in digital safety and ethics.”On April  it was reported Apple had refused to downgrade its privacy rules, which the NHS app needed to work.On April  Halfcocked said the app was crucial and would be rolled out in a matter of weeks. On April , a parliamentary committee was told it would be ready in a fortnight, and the Apple Google version of a tracing app had been rejected as it would slow us down quite considerably. All tracing apps rely on bluetooth connections between phones, but they store data dferently. The UK insisted all contacts be uploaded automatically onto a central server, regardless of health status Apple and Google kept data offline on your phone, pinging warnings out to anonymised contacts only when an infection is confirmed. The international version would also be built into operating systems, putting it on billions of phones worldwide, rather than relying on people specically downloading it.Most of the world went with Apple and Google. In Europe, only Britain and France insisted on a homebrew. On April  Germany switched sides, announcing a national app would not run on iPhones unless the screens were unlocked and the app running.Halfcocked doubled down. By then contracts had been signed with a bunch of private companies to provide software engineers, data processing centres, and servers.On April , the government announced the app would be tested on the Isle of Wight. Hancock said it was islandersapos civic duty to download it. On May , the Health Service Journal reported claims it was not fit for inclusion in the NHSapos own app library, had not passed basic cybersecurity tests, and was “wobbly”. On May , barristers warned the government might be sued over privacy and data protection concerns, and cyber experts said it was open to trolling, and foreign spies shutting down entire cities with fake reports.The same day, Halfcocked said the app was a very, very positive step in terms of us all being able to get some of our liberty back”. It was reported, again, the app wouldnapost work on locked iPhones, and would make safe international travel impossible.On May , Isle of Wight users said it didnapost work on older iPhones, Australia announced it was going with Apple Google after its own app didnapost work well enough, and the government had given £.m to a Swiss firm to seeit could somehow blend the Apple technology with the British app.On May , it was revealed the NHSX app was being rebuilt. On May , the government said it was not. Experts, again, said they were worried the NHSX version relied on self-reporting, rather than a diagnostic test, leaving it open to trolls and abuse. On May , NHSX finally admitted the app didnapost work on older phones. On May , MPs heard the UK app would not work with the Irish version, so any cross-border infections in Northern Ireland would not be picked up.Yet on May , Halfcocked boasted to Parliament: We now have the elements we need to roll out our national Test  Trace service – the testing capacity, the tracing capability and the technology. It was announced, again, the app would be rolled out within weeks.  Apple and Google launched their app - the one that would slow us down - on May . Four days later, the Department of Health gave £million to local authorities so their public health experts could help with tracking and tracing.On May , the Mirror revealed the PMaposs chief adviser had broken lockdown rules while infectious. On May , we revealed heaposd done so twice. On May , Halfcocked set , human contract tracers to work before the app was ready, and said he was getting people used to the idea. A DoH announcement said it would be complemented by the app in coming weeks. On May , he bent maths to announce heaposd hit his target of , tests a day early.  Halfcocked did not mention the app in his opening statements at the daily coronavirus briefings on June , ,  or . On June  the UK Statistics Authority said his figures were far from complete and comprehensible. On June , he thanked Serco - one of the firms involved in the app - for its assistance in the tracing programme.This week, Parliament was told the app would not be ready until winter and, besides, it was not a priority. Yesterday,  weeks after sanity required it, the government abandoned it.Turns out, the NHSX app didnapost work on older phones. It drained battery le. There were privacy concerns. Oh, and it and only traced % of an infected personaposs contacts, so you might as well have thrown all those millions into the English Channel along with a few thousand extra dead bodies.It was going to be available in weeks,  weeks ago. It was being tested, before the code was even written. The much-slower Apple Google app was produced quicker, works better, and was probably cheaper. Country after country hit problems and changed direction, but Halfcocked ploughed on. Sources, leaks, experts, and barristers all pointed out issues, but millions were spaffed up a wall trying to get the Swiss to do something weaposd have been sued for. Most of the developed world now has a phone app but we do not, and Halfcocked refuses to tell us when we might.Itaposs now obvious the app would never have achieved the critical mass of % that Parliament was told it needed, and that contact tracing was botched, then rushed out early to save embarrassment over ious Cummings and goings. Easing lockdown is now even less safe than it was, which was not very.And it seems as though Halfcocked is the worst kind of gambler - stupid. He fell for the apossunk cost fallacyapos - the idea that,you spend enough cash, a payout is guaranteed. Iceland has the worldaposs highest uptake of a coronavirus-tracing app, at % of its population. Its health minister has said it was not a game-changer. The UK government must have known, but gave millions to tech firms rather than the public health officials who were actually capable of saving lives.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brave five-year-old double amputee has raised almost £, for the NHS childrenaposs hospital that saved his le - after only setting out to raise £. Tony Hudgell set his modest target at the start of his efforts to walk  kilometreson his prosthetic legs and crutches in aid of the Evelina London Childrenaposs Hospital in Lambeth. He spent three months under their care after suffering horric physical abuse from his biological parents at just  days old. His injuries, which led to sepsis and multiple organ failure, were so severe that he eventually had to have both legs amputated at the knee.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email.     During the coronavirus lockdown Tony has been learning to walk on his new prosthetics by setting his fundraising challenge to walk every day in June. His adoptive parents Paula and Mark Hudgell, from Kings Hill, Kent, wanted to thank the hospital for saving the little boyaposs le, and hoped family and friends would help them reach their initial target of £. But the youngsteraposs amazing efforts - inspired when he saw -year-old Captain Sir Tom Moore walking laps of his garden to raise a staggering £ million for the NHS - have captured hearts and donations worldwide. Tonyaposs JustGiving total now stands at £, and with nine days of walking still to go, Tony is setting his sights very high.  His mum Paula, , said: Ask Tony how much money he wants to raise and he says five million thousand pounds. He obviously has no concept of money but is a very strong, determined little boy andhe wants something heaposll set about his way of getting it, so who knows. But he is very modest and is absolutely blown away - we all are - by the kindness and generosity of everyone who has taken the time to donate to such a great cause and to send us such wonderful messages of support. We can never thank the Evelina enough for what they did for Tony, and will continue to do until he is . Everyone there is like family to us and we are just so honoured and privileged to give so much back. We wanted to raise something to go towards the care of other children but this is just mind-blowing. It will make such a dference to the hospital that saved Tonyaposs le. The total however is likely to be much higher once separate online and gt aid donations have been added.  Those cheering him on have included Cha FC captain Cesar Azpilicueta, who sent the young Blues fan one of his shirts signed by all the team and manager Frank Lampard. Azpilicueta has invited Tony to the clubaposs training ground once lockdown restrictions are eased. Tony has covered around  metres a day at a green near his home since June . It has raised hopes that Tony – who also has a dislocated left hip,  arthritis  and partial deafness from the abuse – might one day walk unsupported.  Paula told the Sunday Mirror earlier this month: “When I brought Tony home he was four months old, tiny and withdrawn. He was extremely poorly, his legs in plaster and arms only out of plaster the day before. Looking at what he’s achieved, you can’t imagine he’s the same child. “We wanted him to have a challenge to seehis prosthetics would work. Since starting, he is stronger and can move so fast.” Thanking readers for their good wishes, she added: “We’re so thankful for everyone’s love and support. We’ve kept all the messages in a memory box for Tony.”  Paula and finance worker Mark, , are fighting for a “Tony’s Law” for tougher sentences for cruelty cases, with le terms for perpetrators. Biological parents Jody Simpson, , and Tony Smith, , were jailed for  years each in  for causing his injuries but will be eligible for early release in September .  Full-time carer Paula said: “More must be done to protect children.” Caroline Gormley of Evelina London said: “We are so proud Tony is part of our family.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brazen gang of burglars filmed themselves flaunting wads of cash and bags of designer gear from Selfridges after raiding homes and stealing £,. The shameless criminals had previously stolen a safe from a country house in Illston on the Hill, near Kibworth, last year and made a short video showing them with bags of notes. The group of five men then went on a designer shopping spree at the Selfridges department store, in Birminghamaposs Bullring Shopping Centre. They blew £, on flash clobber and even took a group photograph of themselves standing outside the store surrounded by designer carrier bags. Leicestershire Police have now shared the short video and images after the brazen thieves were sentenced for their crimes at Leicester Crown Court, last week.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email As reported by LeicestershireLive, the defendants were responsible for a string of break-ins across the county. Oliver Read, , Barry Kew Moss, , Aurel Sadiki, , and Jacob Wesley, , were sentenced on Friday June, while a -year-old youth, who canapost be named for legal reasons, was sentenced for a series of offences on June . The safe was stolen in a break-in at a country house in Main Street, Illston on the Hill, in the early hours of Friday September , last year. A Land Rover Discovery used to transport the safe was also stolen in a raid on a house in Hallaton, Harborough district, on the same night, as was a Mercedes AMG during another break-in at a house in Leicester. In the early hours of October , last year, a house was then broken into in Shepshed, where an Audi A and Mercedes  were stolen. The court heard footage from one of the gangaposs mobile phones also showed the stolen safe being cracked open.  • Oliver Read, of Aylestone Lane, Wigston, pleaded guilty to the Illston on the Hill burglary, theft of motor vehicle from this address and the burglary in Hallaton. He was sentenced to three years. • Barry Kew-Moss, of Limehurst Avenue, Loughborough, admitted to the Illston on the Hill burglary, theft of motor vehicle from this address, burglary in Hallaton, burglary in Leicester and theft of motor vehicle from this address. He was sentenced to three years and nine months.  • Aurel Sadiki, of Poplar Road, Shelthorpe, Loughborough, pleaded guilty to the Illston on the Hill burglary, theft of motor vehicle from this address, burglary in Hallaton, burglary in Leicester and theft of motor vehicle from this address. He was sentenced to four years and six months. • Jacob Wesley, of Aneford Road, Northfields, Leicester admitted to the Illston on the Hill burglary, theft of motor vehicle from this address, burglary in Hallaton, burglary in Leicester, theft of motor vehicle from this address and burglary in Shepshed. He was sentenced to three years and nine months.  • The -year-old defendant pleaded guilty to the Illston on the Hill burglary, the burglary in Hallaton and a further two attempted burglaries in Syston on October . They also admitted to burglary in Loughborough on October  and a charge of taking without owners consent, relating a vehicle stolen in Leicester on October . He was sentenced on June  to a three year youth rehabilitation order. Speaking at the conclusion of the case, Detective Constable Stephen Henderson, of Leicestershire Police, said: This group was responsible for a number of car key breaks over the county last year, breaking into houses to steal high value cars and on one occasion stole a safe containing a substantial amount of money.

These photos show what was believed to be the first drive-in gig during the lockdown and others are planned until it is safe to pack arenas and bars again. There was an  car limit - at a cost of £ per vehicle - as three bands played to a few hundred fans in front of Royal Victoria Chapel in Netley, near Southampton, Hampshire. Tickets sold out in a day and each car was allowed to have as many as five people, with concertgoers sitting on car bonnets or roofs, or in garden chairs as they practised social distancing and followed coronavirus lockdown rules.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email.     Many people brought their own alcohol and picnics to enjoy the evening of music as three local bands - Sean McGowan, Me And The Moon, and Bash - took to the stage. The evening finished with McGowan getting everyone to toot their car horns and flash their lights for a bit of fun. Tom Chance, , and his we Aeysha Chance, , took their four-month-old baby daughter Sofia to her first gig.Tom Said: We came from Bassett in Southampton, we fancied a night out and have been looking forward to getting out the house. Who knows, this may be the future of music venues going forward. It’s a fantastic idea, with social distancing enforced. We do go to gigs and this is Sophia’s first one and wasn’t quite how we imagined it would work out, but we are here and its great. Organiser George Rashbrook, of SoundLevel Events, said the event came together very quickly and was a success. He said: It went really really well tonight. It could not have gone better, everything from the audience to the weather to the music, its been absolutely perfect.  We had  cars with up to five people per car so about - people. He added: It was organised really quickly, in about four weeks but it was an absolute slog, some real hard graft to put it all together. It is licensed by the council which went well as we work with them regularly with other gigs at other council run facilities. We contacted them to run the idea past them and they bought into it straight away and loved it.  From there we spoke with Hampshire Constabulary who had no issues with it at all. Everyone has been really supportive. We had people either in their cars, or just to the left of their cars so everyone was socially distant with their own little safe bubble. George is now planning another aposdrive-inapos gig for July  at the same price and with the same capacity of  cars. He said:hoping after the success of tonight the council may re-do their risk assessment and allow us a few more, there is certainly the demand for it. Meanwhile, huge arena concerts could be running again by autumn, venue bosses say - but with huge changes to the gig experience. Fans could have to walk through disinfectant mists and have their temperatures taken on the way in to venues. Concertgoers could also be required to wear masks, and staff will have to wear PPE under plans being considered. Drinkers would be encouraged to order pints on smartphone apps and pubs could be patrolled to ensure social-distancing measures are enforced under plans to ease the lockdown for the hospitality sector. Boris Johnson is expected to make an announcement next week on pubs, cafes, restaurants and hotels - with their reopening in England an ambition from July  to start reviving the ailing economy. With the coronavirus alert level having been reduced from four to three on Friday, the Prime Minister believes he has some space to relax measures in a boost for the sector. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden told BBC Radio  that the review the PM ordered into the two-metre social distancing rule for England would be concluded within the coming days, while Whitehall officials confirmed the outcome is expected next week. The rule seeks to slow the spread of Covid- but would be a heavy restraint on the hospitality sector when it reopens, with many bosses favouring the distance being reduced.  Guidance drawn up by the sector and ministers is understood to encourage pubgoers to order drinks using apps instead of going to the bar, while current legislation was said to include the powers for patrols. The downgrading of the alert level by the UKaposs chief medical officers, including Professor Chris Whitty, means transmission of coronavirus is no longer considered to be high or rising exponentially. Localised outbreaks of Covid- are still likely to occur, the advisers warned, and the virus remains in general circulation. On Friday, Mr Johnson told the public to watch this space when asked whether the distance restriction could be reduced to help schools in Englandin autumn.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA new coronavirus tracker has been found on smartphones despite owners not downloading it. Google and Apple have automatically installed the new feature, called aposCovi- Exposure Loggingapos, to help track the spread of the virus. Although it has been automatically installed on most phones it is currently turned off and not available to use. This is because it must be used in conjunction with the countryaposs contact-tracing app, which is still under construction, Kent Online reports. The government has reportedly abandoned its own official app before its even left its testing stage despite spending millions of pounds and months on the technology. Instead, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the NHS would use an alternative app designed by Apple and Google - which is reportedly still months away from being ready. Mr Hancock said he was unable to put a launch date on the app but it should be available in the autumn or winter. The appaposs aim is to trace anyone that a person with coronavirus symptoms came into contact with and alert them to self-isolate.  So what has been installed on my phone  Itaposs not actually an app, it is the technology to assist a future app - the Exposure Notication API. And even when the app is available, it wonapost be mandatory to download it as the NHS has said people will always have the choice of whether or not to download the app. The Exposure Notication API is automatically turned off and even after downloading the app, users can switch it off whenever they want in their phoneaposs settings. Where do I find this API   iPhone users can find it in their settings. Go to privacy, then select health and itaposll come up as the first tab. A description underneath reads: When enabled, iPhone can exchange random IDs with other devices using Bluetooth. This enables an app to noty youyou may have been exposed to Covid-. Exposure Logging cannot access any data in, or add any data to, the Health app.  On Android phones, the tracker is kept under apossettingsapos and then aposgoogle settingsapos. A description on Android reads: Your phone uses Bluetooth to securely collect and share random IDs with other phones that are nearby. Random IDs are automatically deleted after  days.

Laura Davies and Dave Buchanan live in their so-called ‘Earthship’ in the Almeria province of Andalucia, in Spain.The couple became expats having moved to Spain in  and initially purchased an old Cortijo, a type of traditional rural dwelling.Earthships are an idea that originated from American architect, Michael Reynolds, and are essentially a sustainable property constructed from local and waste materials, such as old tyres and drink cans.As dreamy as it sounds, it didnapost all go according to plan for the pair, as Laura admits the project took two years to complete. And Dave also suffered a very nasty injury during the building process. Laura said: “Dave had an accident with the bench saw during construction. After searching and finding the land, the pair met with the local town planner to discuss how to get permission to build and submitted their creative project to the council which was approved one year later.  The walls of the home itself are made entirely from car tyres which Laura and Dave collected from their local garage. They insist they work well at achieving a constant temperature of at least C throughout the year. Meanwhile, the inside of the walls are made from drink cans and bottles held together with mud and papier-mache.  The roof is from local pine beams and collects rainwater, which the couple use for washing, cooking, irrigating in-house planters and for the toilet. Hot water and electricity are generated through the use of solar . The insulation is natural cork from a forests near Valencia and the front of the building is glass. Acting much like a greenhouse, It also allows them to grow food. It creates solar heat and light to keep them warm during winter.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn eerie abandoned farmhouse left frozen in time provided one photographer with a fascinating look into rural le more than  years ago. The home in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, looks ordinary from the outside, but inside it is packed with newspapers dating back to , stopped clocks, a half-smoked pipe, and the owneraposs shoes left by the bed years after the property was vacated. Photographer Rebecca was invited in to see the decaying cottage after its owner died and she was left in awe of the haunting scenes within the perfectly preserved home. The cottage was lived in until  by the last of three brothers, who kept all of their family history, alongside tins of food from the early th century left unopened on the kitchen shelves.A man only identied as Dessie was the last to live there, leading aposa solitary le among the relics of the pastapos before moving into a home in  and passing away two years later. Rebecca, who owns the Abandoned NI website sharing photos of the derelict houses she explores, was allowed in by the owner to get a record of the incredible space before it was knocked down to make way for a new build. She said she was left gobsmacked by what she found, with old books, magazines, papers and photographs littered around the farm workeraposs cottage and left untouched. A clock on the mantel piece is stuck showing ., a pair of glasses are left ready to pick up and a rusted OXO tin has been left open, with two pocket watches stored inside. Hundreds of handwritten letters fill the drawers, and three kettles are sat on the stove, next to a cup which appears to have been placed there just before it was abandoned. Old books and newspapers including the Mid Ulster Mail from  were left sitting in the living room which had been shut off for more than  years, alongside one newspaper which reported the aftermath of the sinking of the Titanic in . Upstairs there remained rotting bedclothes, a bed pan on the floor and a flat cap left hanging on the end of a bedframe. Rebecca said she initially wasnapost surethe interior would be very interesting, but she has now created an exhibition based on the lives of Dessie and his family.  She said: I have to admit I saw the outside and wasnapost sureit was worth it. As soon as I opened the door I was blown away. I went into what I thought was a wee cottage and itaposs basically a social history museum. The cottage first appeared on maps in  and Rebecca began researching the family to help piece together the puzzle in all of the photographs. After talking to people to find out more about Dessie, she said: Among many things he was a fabulous cook, many friends still talk about his famous soda bread which he cooked over the original stove. He was a hearty farmer, milking cows to produce milk and butter.It was reportedyou stayed for dinner in the house and you finished up, you were given another dinner for seconds.No one left with an empty stomach. One of the mysteries Rebecca was able to solve was personal items belonging to an Edwin McQueen, who she was able to discover was married to Dessieaposs mum. He worked as a policeman, and a certicate from  and a framed picture of him in his unorm was found in one of the bedrooms.

Jake says that the company offered to flatten his garden to compensate for the issues that arose from the building work. But the problems didn’t stop there.
