title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  George Square needs to be completely overhauled - here   s why
story: The new station completely transforms the look and feel of this part of town. What a shame, then, about the second thing I couldnrsquot help noticing: how drab and disappointing George Square remains.Granted, the grim sight of loyalist protesters wrapped in Union flags ldquoprotecting the statues and Cenotaph didnrsquot help. But even without their isive presence the cityrsquos historic square is a let-down, visually, socially and culturally, a frustrating waste of urban space that could and should be far better utilised.Where other European squares create buzz and atmosphere with year-round arts, culture, food and shopping attracting locals and visitors, George Square is dreary and uninspiring: a few trees, some benches and a clutch of dull, predictable th-century statues ndash ldquogreat men and Queen Victoria ndash that few feel any kinship with. The only part of the square that has any real purpose and meaning is the Cenotaph.The idea that George Square is in serious need of a makeover is nothing new, of course, and there have been ious  dawns and broken promises over the years, not least the outrageous fiasco of  ndash remember that  ndash which wasted huge amounts of public money and goodwill alike. But the two defining events of  - coronavirus and the Black Lives Matter protests -offer Glasgow the best opportunity in a generation to finally get this right and transform George Square into the vibrant civic centre Glaswegians deserve.Letrsquos start with the pandemic, which will continue to damage the economic and social pull of town and city centres. As lockdown restrictions are gradually lted we will grasp a new reality ndash fewer shops, restaurants, bars and cultural attractions than before, with those that do re-open unable to work at full capacity for now. Answers to the sort of questions around attracting people to city centres that were already stumping businesses, planners and local authorities even before coronavirus hit have become all the more pressing.Thatrsquos where a proper revamp of George Square comes in, a key step forward in boosting Glasgowrsquos economy and cultural capital in the wake of the pandemic. What should the square contain  That would be for citizens to decide, but herersquos a few quick ideas that presume an eventual end to social distancing: an ampitheatre for live music, theatre and comedy, proper seating, pop-up pods for community groups, a food and craft market, arts and exhibition space, murals, a garden and childrenrsquos play area.As for the fate of the statues, again, it would be for the people to decide whether they still have a place in this new urban realm. Not that we would want to forget our past, of course. But surely we can find new and more creative ways to confront, commemorate and celebrate it, taking in voices that were previously ignored ndash women, ethnic minorities, working class people, gay people, the disabled ndash reflecting the ersity of our city as it is now.Rather than an expensive international competition for designs ndash letrsquos learn from  ndash a three-month public consultation could be held, and a  of local architects, planners, artists, businesspeople and community groups convened to create perhaps three dferent plans, which would then be voted on by the people of Glasgow. Granted, such an ambitious revamp wouldnrsquot be easy to fund in the dficult years ahead, but with a crucial economic and culturalat stake, it should be prioritised. Surely a mixture of public, private and philanthropic funding could be sourced Glasgow City Council has already started the conversation that could make all this happen, by bringing forward the pedestrianisation of George Square and suspending a third of city centre parking bays to make room for walkers and cyclists.I would urge council leader Susan Aitken and her team to think bigger. A commitment to redesign George Square would offer an exciting, positive and inclusive focus for Glaswegians in the tough months ahead. The end result could be what Glasgow has been crying out for for a generation: a proud and modern civic centrepiece that is worthy of our great city, a place that excites, entertains, and educates, that makes us feel part of something bigger. Wersquove never needed it more.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: coronavirus-scotlands-slow-steady-exit-already-working
story: As she outlined a staged approach to Phase  that has delayed any change to physical distancing for now and kicked the re-opening of beer gardens into the long grass, the First Minister told MSPs that "patience could reap our greatest rewards"."The prize for going more slowly now is a recovery that is much more sustainable and one that will, I hope, allow more normality toto our daily lives," said Ms Sturgeon.: A guide to some of Scotlands best beer gardensSince the UK began moving out of lockdown, Scotland has generally moved at a slightly slower pace: overall, we spent longer under lockdown, our schools remain closed, and non-essential shops will have to wait two weeks longer than Englands to re-open.One potentially interesting trend has emerged already.For most of May, both Scotland and England were recording roughly the same Covid death rate per day: in both countries it tracked steadily downwards from seven per million population around May  to around four per million by the end of May.Since then, however, the trajectory has split, with Scotland declining faster to fewer than one Covid death per day for every million people, while Englands is around three per million.How much that is down to the social distancing measures in place, or simply the populations compliance with them health experts said risked eroding the publics cooperation is impossible to say.But it appears that the goal for Ms Sturgeon is not just to suppress the virus but to get as close as possible to eradicating it.Stringent social distancing, contact tracing and quarantining snuffed out SARS  years ago. New Zealand has achieved much the same with Covid: it had had no new cases at all for  days, until two UK visitors tested positive this week.The lower the prevalence of the virus within the population, the easier it is to pinpoint and contain new clusters, prevent a second wave and allow a fullerto normalityalbeit at a later date.Whatever our progress, Scotland recorded  new cases between May  and June , so eradication is still elusive.: Why the science has no clear-cut answers to Scotlands two-metre dilemmaIn this context, the decision not to re-open beer gardens is all about a better result later: for example, reducing virus prevalence enough that physical distancing can be halved to one metre in time for the hospitality traderesuming on July .Ms Sturgeon said there is emerging evidence that pubs, restaurants and gyms are "hotspots for transmission". Japanese research found that the risk of infection is around  times higher indoors than outdoors.So why is it safe to open outdoor food markets but not beer gardens  One theory is that people in beer gardens spend a prolonged period in same company, increasing the risk of transmissionsomeone in the group is infected but not yet showing symptoms.They are also more likely to talk loudly, shout, or even singwhich is also linked to transmission. At two metres, the risk of infection is an estimated % at one metre, %. But the less virus in the population as a whole, the less relevance that risk dferential holds.

title: sand-dune-restoration-project-way-support-rare-wildlife-species
story: So vital are sand dunes to preserving Scotlandrsquos beaches and acting as natural buttresses against climate change, conservationists have developed a new method of restoring them to help prevent erosion that threaten the natural ridges.Pioneered by Forestry and Land Scotland , the project, at a site near Tain in East Sutherland, aims to remove trees that were planted decades ago in a misguided attempt to prevent dune erosion and create the conditions that will allow dune vegetation to once more take hold and allow natural processes to conserve the coastline.:Winners and losers as lockdown is relaxed at lastSuzanne Dolby, FLS Environment forester , said: ldquoSand dunes are vulnerable to coastal erosion, especially in the face of rising sea levels and more frequent severe weather events.ldquoDecades ago, the thinking was that planting trees on dunes would help to prevent them from being eroded and that this would help protect Scotlandrsquos coastline. However, tidal and wave action continued to drive erosion under the tree roots and actually encouraged erosion.ldquoThese days, the awareness and understanding of the cycles that sand dunes go through ndash and their value as habitats in their own right ndash is much more prevalent so we are looking at how best we can restore sand dunes to their natural state.Sand dunes help to protect the coastline and are likely to be an increasingly important defence against sea level rise as a result of the Climate Emergency.Natural and healthy dune systems change their formation in response to wave, wind and tidal action, with some sand removed only to then be replaced at a later stage with deposits of new sand.This self-sustaining process can play out in the course of one storm but more often occurs over many years and,viewed at a particular moment in the cycle, could give the impression that the dunes are disappearing.Tree planting in previous generations attempted to stop this apparent erosion and fix the dunes in place ndash but it also interrupted the natural process of replenishment, as well as the colonisation of dune vegetation.Ms Dolby said: ldquoPrevious restoration attempts over the last  years have failed to properly restore open dunes because they did not deal with a surface layer on the dunes that had been enriched by fallen leaves or needles, conditions which favour woodland plants and that effectively prevented more sensitive dune plants from surviving.ldquoThe method wersquore trialling now involves removing the trees and scrub and scraping and burying the plant litter layer to leave a bare sand surface, which will hopefully support the rare vegetation special to these dunes.The trial site, at Morrich More, will be closely monitored over the next five years to assess the effectiveness of the restoration process.Scotlandrsquos more than , hectares of sand dune systems are considered among some of the countryrsquos most valuable habitats, thought to support more than  rare species.Risks to the dunes include coner plantations which have already claimed around , hectares and sea buckthorn which has colonised signicant areas of sand dune in parts of south-east Scotland. This non-native shrub, like the tree project, was originally planted to combat erosion, but has itself become a problem.In , Scottish Natural Heritagerevealed that Donald Trumprsquos Aberdeenshire golf resort could lose its status as a protected wildle site after the sand dunes at Menie no longer included enough of the special features for which they were designated a site of special scientic interest .:Wrapping up the Eighties with Runrig, Jesus and Mary Chain, Del Amitri and Deacon BlueThe designation is given to areas with rare species of fauna or flora, or with important geological or physiological features.A three month consultation on the future status of Foveran Links SSSI began that June, but was postponed until this year only four months later.In official documents SNH said Menie Links Golf Course had ldquoadversely affected the sand dune habitat with  per cent of the total SSSI lost and % of the sand dune habitat gone.Mr Trump was granted permission to build a golf course at the site despite concerns about damage to the dunes and the links opened in .SNH said evidence showed permanent habitat loss following the construction of fairways and greens, and that the stabilisation of mobile sand ldquohas destroyed the dynamic nature of the site.Trump International said the move by the Government body was politically motivated and a ldquostitch-up.

title: fathers-day-dad-taught-us-taught
story: Sure, the interminable Fatherrsquos Day offerings at the supermarkets still play to the stereotype ndash Jason Statham boxset, anyone  ndash but beyond the cliche of the sofa-bound dad enjoying a bonanza of beer, crisps and football therersquos a truer picture, one of a more participatory father who may even feel embarrassment at being asked to put his feet up and crack open a cold one today when he could be vacuuming the curtains, washing the sheets and preparing three dferent lunches for the kids.Okay, perhaps thatrsquos taking things a little too far. Many a cold one will be cracked open today, some football might be watchedand a study published last month shows that even in lockdown women are still doing most of the housework and childcare. Still, therersquos no denying the fact that in the span of the le of, say, Brooklyn Beckham, an awful lot about fatherhood that was once taken for granted has shted. And probably forever.I use Beckham Jnr as a useful measure of change because dad David was the original ldquometrosexual, a term implying a degree of vanity and a working knowledge of moisturiser but also a break-down of traditional gender roles, and it was from the metrosexual that the New Dad sprang.Brooklyn Beckham became  in March, meaning a generation has grown up and come of age in an era in which fathers ndash those self-same New Dads ndash have seen their rights regarding parental leave strengthened and codied, the expectations placed on them increased accordingly, and a wealth of research published that covers everything from the hormonal changes that occur when men become fathers to the cognitive benefits that accrue to babies and toddlers from increased interaction with their dads. At the same time, more men are working from home.The stay-at-home dad who acts as main carer while his partner goes out to work isnrsquot an anomaly, hersquos a fixture of virtually any primary school playground in the country. Thatrsquos progress.Put it another way: for men who have become fathers in the last couple of decades it means priorities have been re-calibrated, ambitions re-addressed and measures of success re-defined.The distant disciplinarian who valued worth in terms of the regularity of his promotions and the weight of his pay packet has been edged out of the picture by a guy who does the school drop-off and pick-up, can handle a nappy, knows that NCT isnrsquot a kind of sports car and who, most of all, is involved in his childrenrsquos lives in a way which is dferent from the past and which sets a template for the future.:Its  years since Checkpoint Charlie was torn down but could the Allies have stopped it going up Here, we meet a selection of Scottish men, hear how fatherhood has changed and affected them ndash and learn what their children make of their efforts so far.Derek Dick, , is a singer-songwriter best known as Marillion frontman Fish, and passionate gardener ndash see funnyfarmkitchengarden online. His daughter Tara Nowy, , works in PR and is a former model.DerekWhat has your child taught you The mysteries of social media and that most tech does not respond to swearing loudly at it.What one thing would you wish to teach her and why How to grow her own food and discover the myriad benefits of gardening. With the ldquonew normal on its way we need to relearn old skills and discover whatrsquos important. She is, I am proud to say, now standing at the garden gate. Peace has no price.What did your dad teach you To always be open, honest, caring and understanding of others, that money is not to be worshipped, a betrayal should never be a surprise, family is of paramount importance and I should always be there for my daughter.What is the biggest sacrice your dad made for you Buying season tickets for Hibs in the early s so we could at least spend a few hours together at Easter Road away from his ever-demanding commitment to the family garage business.:The remarkable secrets of Edinburgh landmark Arthurs SeatThe tears of despair over the years in pursuit of the ever elusive ldquoholy grail of the Scottish Cup were finally all made worth it when we lted the trophy in May . Tara and I both saw him in hospital the day after the match and he left us the next day with the biggest smile on his face. A perfect send-off.What was your dadrsquos relationship like with his own dad Love and emotions were not expressed well during their letimes. My dad worshipped his father, but it was, at times, a dficult relationship as my grandfather was a very uncompromising alpha male, a product of First World War experiences. My dad and I talked about him a lot when we both got older and had a very close relationship. My father was scared of him and respected and loved him deeply at the same time. We all continue to learn from the previous generationrsquos mistakes.TaraWhat has your dad taught you To stand my ground, to stand up for what I believe in. But, most importantly, never to judge anyone by their colour, creed or background.If you had a child, what would you want to teach them I would want our relationship to be as close as mine with my parents. A lot of that comes from being open about your feelings and talking things through.How dferent do you think le is for you than it was for your dad There were definite dferences before, but I feel everything is about to change a whole lot more after this pandemic, hopefully for the better, socially and economically, as we have all had time to reflect and learn.What is the biggest sacrice your dad has made for you My mum got cancer when I was small and my dad came off tour to look after the family through that tough time.The MacPhee family hail from South Uist. Kerry MacPhee, , is a cyclist and community liaison officer based in Stirling and her father Don, , is skipper on the Renfrew Ferry. He recently hit the headlines after ing into the River Clyde to save a woman.DonWhat has your child taught you Having children is a great leveller. What always intrigued me when Kerry and her four siblings were growing up is getting that childrsquos view and how often what they said was completely unexpected.What one thing would you wish to teach them and why That everyone is equal. Very quickly they learned that appearance is not the way to judge a person.What did your dad teach you No matter who are dealing with, sit and talk to the person ndash not to the job, status, or suit.:"A lot of people hated Marc. And they thought I was the boyfriend." Dave Ball on le in and out of Soft CellWhat is the biggest sacrice your dad made for you His time. He was a schoolteacher and when he wasnrsquot working, I would always tag along with him. Wersquod go fishing and out on the hills doing the peat. When I had my own kids, I understood the value of engaging with your children in whatever you were doing, be it taking apart an engine or butchering a sheep.What was your dadrsquos relationship like with his own dad They were very close, like most island families are. My dad died when I was . Afterwards I became known as ldquoDon Theresa because Theresa was my motherrsquos name. As is tradition, most of the other lads were known after their fathers.KerryWhat has your dad taught you A wee nugget of simple advice in Gaidhlig, ldquoCum arsquo dol. In English, it means keep going. Hersquos a grafter of a man, a typical islander spinning a dozen plates at once who will never say no to helping someone.If you had a child, what would you want to teach them The importance of community. By that, I mean having their own strong tribe of friends who, outwith their family network, are people they could ask for help and equally give support to.If you could teach your dad one thing, what would it be Sometimes itrsquos okay to say no to people.How dferent do you think le is for you than it was for your dad He has been an island man pretty much all his le. My dad left South Uist for secondary school in Fort William and a brief period at university, although never for very long. Irsquove been in Stirling since I left home for university and had opportunities he never did.What is the biggest sacrice your dad has made for you When I was growing up, my dad was a scallop er. Thatrsquos a tough gig to provide for your family. Hersquos had the bends from ing, which was serious, but still kept going. The smell of Fairy washing-up liquid always reminds me of him because he would get one of us to cover the zip across the shoulders of his ing suit with it to help yank it closed or open.Niall Mackenzie is a three times British Superbikes champion and former Grand Prix rider. His son Taylor competes in British SuperbikesNiallWhat has your child taught you That I donrsquot know it all. I had a defining moment in  when we were having a heated debate about his riding. Taylor said: ldquoDonrsquot just tell me what Irsquom doing wrong, tell me how to do things correctly and Irsquoll do my best to change.:Shyness, love and lives of quiet desperation: the art of Alan BennettI walked off and had a chat with myself, and took that on board. Also, I realised then constructive criticism and support is much more productive than criticism.What one thing would you wish to teach him My job is more or less done now but from early on I made manners, looking everyone straight in the eye and shaking handsa priority. Basic stuff, but it has served him well.What did your dad teach you He was a fan of the Queenrsquos English so he taught me the importance of speaking properly. I grew up on a very working class council estate in central Scotland and communicated in as much slang and rough language as the next guy, however, in his company I spoke dferently. That served me well when I began to travel and meet people in later le. He also taught me to drive a car while at primary school, which was awesome.What is the biggest sacrice your dad made for you Having me. He was  when I was conceived with his much younger second we Amelia . I wasnrsquot planned and my mum hid her pregnancy until the day I was born. She complained of indigestion at work, disappeared at lunchtime and came back with me. Despite all of this I was always very much loved and cared for.What was your dadrsquos relationship like with his own dad His dad died before I was born, but I think his relationship was similar to mine with my dad. He had lots of brothers and sisters but my dad was encouraged to spread his wings so went to work in the tea industry in India in his early twenties. His dad was the station master at Forres.TaylorWhat has your dad taught you That he can fix almost anything with Jubilee clips, duct tape and Araldite.If you had a child, what would you want to teach them and why That you shouldnrsquot fix most things with Jubilee clips, duct tape and Araldite. Doing things properly is better in the long run.If you could teach your dad one thing, what would it be That Google is here now so things can easily be repaired properly without the need for Jubilee clips, duct tape and Araldite. That said, hersquos the kind of guy yoursquod wantyou were stranded on a desert island. Hersquod be the guy that could build a shelter and make a boat.What is the biggest sacrice your dad has made for you A relatively financial secure retirement to fund my early racing career.Douglas MacIntyre has run The Creeping Bent record label since . He is currently making music under the name Port Sulphur. He is the father of five, including Dugald and Sonny.DouglasWhat have your children taught you They have taught me to be more open-minded. I was  when I became a father for the first time, and probably set in my ways. I have five children Amelia , Dugald , Matilda , and Sonny and Flora, who are -year-old twins.:Vanessa Branson on how the Scottish island of Eilean Shona won her heartThey all have an inidual viewpoint.I feel I am constantly learning by looking at the world from their perspective, and have a high regard for young people in general. They are the future.What one thing would you wish to teach them and why Irsquod like to think Irsquove helped pass on some of the basics regarding right and wrong. I have been successful in teaching the boys that there is only one team in Lanarkshire. Both are season ticket holders for Hamilton Academical.What did your dad teach you My dad was brought up in rural South Lanarkshire , and he taught me about natural history, particularly ornithology.We would go out birdwatching most evenings during spring and summer, and I have retained a knowledge of birdsong.He also used the old Scots language names for birds, which caused me some confusion when I started reading my Observer Book of British Birds and learned that thereceivedname for a blue dykie was actually a dunnock. Other Scots names I used for birds when I was growing upincludedwhaup , peeweep , kittieneedle , stuckie , shelffie , hoolet .What was your dadrsquos relationship like with his own dad My dad had a good relationship with his own father, who was a highlander from Corpach who moved to Lanarkshire for employment. He spoke the Scots tongue, which wasabsorbedby my dad and in turn me. They spent most of their spare time fishing for brown trout in local rivers, which, again, is something that has passed down to me and my children.Dugald, What has your dad taught you My dad taught me how to play chess, which I remember playing one weekend when we were in the highlands. He also taught me how to fish for brown trout in the local river, and I have a great memory of going fishing with Dad and Grandpa. He has also taught me what is wrong and what is right.How dferent do you think le is for you than it was for your dad I think our le is easier, and because of the internet we have lots of options and things to do to stop us getting bored.If you could teach your dad one thing, what would it be Irsquod teach him how to play computer games.Sonny, What has your dad taught you How to play football and fish, including setting up a fishing rod. When we went to cycle a stretch of the West Highland Way on mountain bikes, he showed me how start a fireto cook our dinner outdoors at the wooden wigwam we were staying in. If you had a child, what would you want to teach them and why To stick up for yourself and your friends.:Chef Gary Maclean on the enduring magic of New YorkIf you could teach your dad one thing, what would it be How to play FIFA .Compendium by Port Sulphur is now available, creepingbent.net

title: fidelma-cook-unlikely-angels-make-life-worth-living
story: If wersquore lucky, there are times Irsquove discovered over the years, the most unlikely angels appear in onersquos le. Miriam is one although shersquod bof and shrug at such a fancul thought.She and I have nothing in common. No common teenage memories no similar backgrounds or experiences, and often no similar language. She speaks the fastest French Irsquove ever heard, a completely dferent French to my formal, precise own.:Fidelma Cook: You know itrsquos bad when Irsquom asking for a bloody saladWithout the nuances and said unsaid of my own language, my conversation is carried on in broad brush strokes with few of the subtleties I enjoy. Often, I just end up in baffled laughter waving my hands.That suits Miriam actually. She does not waste time in abstract thoughts. One is born, lives as best as one can and dies. There is no point fretting about the things that canrsquot be changed no point fearing or worrying about what may or may not be to come and no point trying to change that which cannot be changed. She is, as she often says, a fatalist.All this implies a rather one-dimensional character. Oh, dear me, no. Miriam has many hidden depths and swirling currents in her which I occasionally glimpse but will never fully see. I suspect she has trained herself to be, on the surface, this passive contented creature for many, many reasons it is not my place to know.Born in Nice, early photographs she has shown me present a sexy, sultry temptress in short shorts obligatory toy dog under arm, leaning provocatively against the railings of the famous Promenade.Married twice, widowed and estranged from her only son, she has had other partners before Pierrot and admits she always needs a man in her le, a relationship, a partnership.She loves to nurture, to cook, to make a man happy and comfortable, leaving him free to do the manly things in the house and grounds. Never would she tell him to make his own lunch or wash and iron his clothes.She darns and repairs his hunting gear and then spends many hours and days alone as he follows his hobbies with no thought for her lonely days. He s for his meals which are always ready at the fixed French times and follow a pattern of his favourite foods.She collects complicated recipes she never makes, for Pierrot limits his tastes to a handful of meat and vegetable dishes and is suspicious of anything new. She sublimates her creativity in front of cable TVrsquos buying channels, sending for all manner of kitchen equipment which spills over into the barn.There are the preserves, sauces, frozen blanched vegetables and foie gras she works at hour after hour from the garden stock. Occasionally she cooks Sunday lunches of many courses for Pierrots ex, his daughters and their husbands.:Fidelma Cook: I must gather the skirts of my remnants of courage and get through this hospital hellThen she is in her element showcasing her classic skills but, having been a guest, I know they eat silently, never praise and head home after the last mouthful.I will never understand her acceptance of her lot and she will never understand my fierce need for independence even at the cost of a le alone with all its flaws.Well, a faux independence that wouldnrsquot have worked these last dficult years without Miriam ndash the ultimate irony.From shy gts of huge bunches of mimosa, vegetables grown in the potager, fruit plucked from her trees, tempting plates of food, over the years delicately aware of never intruding, she made a place in my le and my heart.As I became more accident prone, she did my shopping, got my prescriptions, brought oils and unguents, visited me in many rehabs, baking cakes for the staff and removing my clothes to hand wash and iron, ing them in plastic pouches.She bought me a mini exercise pedalo to keep under my table to work my legs and I have learned not to say I really like something or she s with it, be it a rice pudding or said exercise bike.My cupboards groan with her conserves and rich tomato sauce base and my fridge and freezer with her latest sous-vide concoctions.If she has a fault it is her protective ferocity in acting for me ndash berating medical receptionists, pharmacists for not giving medications in advance. This week it was a bank teller who wouldnrsquot give her more cash than the weekly allowance.She has control of my bank cards as she trusts no-one  to use them except Alistair the IT man gardener.:Fidelma Cook: Sod your retirement villages and keep your hands off my dogNone of my femmes de meacutenage has come up to scratch but so far my cleaner Emilie has proved a match and will not be ousted.And all I can do is take from this generous soul using Christmas as an excuse to buy Miriam cashmere and smart English country jackets. Fine restaurants are wasted for her tastes are specic and anyway she says her food is always better.Oh, I almost forgot her latest talent ndash smuggling. In lockdown all goods brought to me are hr quarantined and may be opened so she hides my e-cigs in sweets and medication, carefully retaping as Irsquove mentioned before."Yoursquod be amazed the things I can do," she says darkly.Ah, she has secrets Irsquoll never penetrate but thank God indeed for Miriam.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: nosh-night-glasgow-ron-mackennas-home-delivery-review
story: GlasgowHEY,yoursquore the person who emailed me a recommendation to try Nosh Night In and yoursquore reading this, thank you. Irsquod have done this by email except I canrsquot find your original message.Nor, not very funnily-enough, could I find the message ordering the food. On Friday, as hunger floated through our house like the ghost of restaurants past, I couldnrsquot even find the online menu, the order receipt, the delivery time or remember the actual name of who I had ordered from. Not a clue either about what kind of food wason its way. Or whether coming hot or cold.This vagueness seemed to irritate my family almost as much as transferring money to a stranger who wasnrsquot apparently a recognised mainstream business annoyed my bank. Scam warning, the bank shouted gleefully. It will never arrive, it gloated. Yoursquore on your own now, it ultimately crowed. Pfff. Asyou are ever anything  with a bank.This all did, nonetheless, highlight the strange new world we live in ndash where transferring dosh for nosh to complete strangers, hoping theyrsquoll turn up whilst having no clue as to the quality of said food, is becoming the norm. And all because upmarket restaurants are either still locked-down or all ordered-up or run annoying website systems demanding log-ins at pre-ordained timeswhich then generate immediate sold-out signs.Nosh Night In  Wersquove gone a bit Terra Incognita here, wandered off the usual culinary map. In fact the missing email mystery will be solved only days letter when I realise I actually did order the whole thing by email. But the woman used her personal email, which confused me.And, yes, the food arrives. On time. Though as Irsquom not actually at home then it falls upon my son to report on a very nice lady who waited at a distance while he unpacked it all in the kitchen and then ed her tray. Timing wont matter anyway. It just requires to be gently heated. And then there are nice, warm, cheery instructions.And those wrappings ndash portending a sense of quality, injecting a mood of anticipation. Lush brown paper abounding, quality corrugated cardboard cartons here, there and everywhere while grease-proof squares unfold like crisp handkerchiefs to release aromas and textures and finally elicit a collective ooh ndash as freshly-made puff ball meringues sparkling with crimson jus start their transformation into tonightrsquos Eton Mess. And a box of handmade tablet too.Can you feel the relief coursing through me So itrsquos already one of those meals where we set the table properly, lay out the nice place mats, and even use that china found online that restores to full bter the wedding present we got many moons ago from the Evening Times reporters.But what about the food  Classy, really. Pretty elegant. A fennel and orange salad lay out juicy orange slices, sprinkle with fine-sliced yet crunchy fennel, then toss on hazelnuts, pour orange-miso dressing and adorn with very fresh leaves of watercress.After that  Chicken breasts are wrapped in prosciutto and sage leaves, served with slightly seared and still buttery new potatoes flavoured themselves with thyme and rocksalt ndash plus there are courgettes roasted with a crust of parmesan.Itrsquos deftly, and very professionally prepared stuff this. And I suddenly look like a genius for ordering it.Wersquove still to eat those crunchy, gooey meringues with fresh strawberries and fresh raspberries from one of the tubs, whipped cream and a sharp proper raspberry sauce from another. And the tablet is yet to be fought over. Which it will be.Wersquore talking about very generous portions in every course. Four meringues for two people, plates more than adequately filled, not to mention the cost of that expensive packaging.This is the probably the best value meal we have had since the lockdown started. If this is the future of eating out whilst still being in: itrsquos looking very good.Menu: Strictly three-course set menu of fennel and orange salad, chicken saltimbocca with marsala sauce, baby roasts and thyme and, to finish, handmade meringues as part of an Eton mess kit.Price: Itrsquos pound per person or pound for two and that includes free delivery in Glasgow ndash small extra charge outwith the boundaries.Food: Despite being a home-delivery the whole meal sparkled with class and a touch of glamour. The food was prepared to a very high standard ndash therersquos something good happening in lockdown catering.Nosh Night InGlasgow sar@nosh-uk

title: 30-years-since-checkpoint-charlie-torn-allies-stopped-going
story: FIRST, the soldiers moved in. Then the workmen arrived and broke up the ground with jackhammers and laid barbed wire and put up fence posts and painted a six-inch white line across the street. There was also a sign that said DIE GRENZE IST GESCHLOSSEN . It was one of the official crossings from East to West Berlin and the most famous it was Checkpoint Charlie.The first sign of trouble on that night ndash August ,  ndash had been the lights on the Branbenburg Gate going out. Residents then reported hearing the sound of hammering and drilling, and people who were trying to get home on the underground suddenly found they could no longer reach their destination. Others discovered streets and houses sealed off as the barrier entombed them. In years to come, the junction of Friedrichstase and Zimmerstrase ndash Checkpoint Charlie ndash would be one of the few points where some people could still get across.The checkpoint would also become a legendary place, a totem of Eastern totalitarianism and Western defiance , a source of tension, a place of blood and hope. In Western culture, and in spy movies in particular, it also became an icon of espionage and escape. And when it all stopped and the Berlin Wall came down, in , Checkpoint Charlie was one of the focal points of celebration too. People climbed on the wall at the checkpoint and shook hands with the guards and asked for their caps as keepsakes.It is now exactly  years since the day the checkpoint was dismantled and it remains one of the symbolic focal points in the history of the Cold War, only these days it is not the place of solemnity and remembrance you would expect. Quite the opposite in fact: there are tourist shops and burger chains and you can get your photo taken with re-enactors posing as guards and that really gets historians like Iain MacGregor down. Iain is a publisher and writer whose paperback, Checkpoint Charlie: The Cold War, the Berlin Wall and The Most Dangerous Place on Earth, is out this month and one of the first trips he made when he was researching the book was to the place where the checkpoint used to be. It was not what hersquod hoped.ldquoIf you go to Checkpoint Charlie, yoursquod think you were in Leicester Square which is a real shame, he says. ldquoA lot of veterans say they canrsquot believe what it looks like. It is beyond tacky. A much more moving place is the nearby memorial to Peter Fechter, the -year-old German bricklayer who was killed in August  near the checkpoint while trying to get across the wall. Peter was shot in the back by the East German guards and was left lying in no manrsquos land, huddled against the wall. It wasnrsquot the first death there, or the last, but the fact that a young man could be left to die while the guards on both sides looked on shocked the world. Iain laid flowers at the site when he was there.For Iain, the fate of Peter Fechter is one of the stories that emphasises just how terrible the wall and its series of checkpoints were. The famous and notorious name Checkpoint Charlie came from the letters of the NATO phonetic alphabet ndash the checkpoint on the autobahn was Checkpoint Alpha, its counterpart at Drewitz was Bravo, and so on ndash and it was the point where military personnel, diplomats, business people and foreign tourists could cross the wall.Others made escape attempts through or near the checkpoint, one of the most daring of which was in  when boiler workers Peter Schopf and brothers Peter and Manfred Hoer dug a tunnel from a building on the East side to the west. All they had was a shovel, a chisel, a hunting kne and a small tin to remove the earth but, after three gruelling and terrying weeks, they were through and emerged just inside the Western zone near the checkpoint.Iain also talks about the suffering of the families that were ided by the wall. ldquoIf you talk to people who are in their s or s now, he says, ldquowho lived through that moment, when you mention the separation, or meeting their friends or relatives again, they are moved to tears. He talks about the bride, still in her wedding dress, waving to her mother and father in the East. Or the nurse, Ida Siekmann, who could no longer bear being separated from her sister Martha, who lived three streets away in the west. Ida threw three eiderdowns from a building on the border to cushion her landing and threw herself out of the window. She died of her injuries.Then there were the conditions that people in the East had to live under. ldquoItrsquos a classic case of what looked on paper like an amazing experiment in equality," says Iain, " but you get behind that veneer and itrsquos a totalitarian state, no question, and you certainly donrsquot raise your head above the parapet. I went to the places where the people who did rebel were sent and I talked to the people who were sent there and once yoursquove done that, you think as soon as they lost the backing of the Soviet Union by , it was a house of cards that was going to crumble.The nature of le in East Germany is clear from the sheer number of people who were working covertly for the state. ldquoIt was a country of about  million people, says Iain, ldquoand one in four was either a Stasi agent or an informant, and some suggest one in three, and that goes to show what kind of police state it was. And that was before you had -hour news surveillance and electronic satellites ndash it was more to do with people power, people watching, people listening, and people informing. Everyone I spoke to knew of or had a close friend that was an informant. It takes a certain type of person to rebel against that.The tension was also high at the pressure points on the wall, including Checkpoint Charlie and in October  it looked like it might spill over into something more serious when a standoff occurred between US and Soviet tanks on either side of the checkpoint. The spark was a dispute over the examination of travel documents by East German border guards and by the end of the stand-off  tanks were facing each other. Eventually an understanding was reached although some of the military personnel who were there at time think itrsquos the closest we came in Germany to World War Three.Iain MacGregor certainly thinks the incident could have turned extremely nasty. ldquoI think we were on the edge in terms of a localised conflict, although I donrsquot think it would gone global like the Cuban missile crisis. It was all over within hours but it was a very dangerous precedent ndash it got out of hand, there was a very belligerent, senior American general, Lucius Clay, and he overruled the commanders on the ground. He was the one that put the tanks down there but the US only had  tanks in the whole of the city and the Russians had at least . The worldrsquos press was there and thatrsquos when it went back up the chain to the Kremlin and the White House and they managed to talk themselves out of it.What the incident demonstrated was that the real military power lay with the Soviets ndash within the confines of the Wall, the Allies simply could not match the power of the East. But an important question remains about how the Allies handled the situation. Could they have prevented the wall and the checkpoints going up in the first place ldquoI think, at a strategic level, politicians and presidents, they were taken by surprise by the wall going up, says Iain, ldquoRefugees were still pouring in to West Berlin, and these refugees were giving reports of troop build-ups and huge dumps of material, wood and stone and barbed wire, but they were giving these reports in dribs and drabs andsomeone had taken the time to put X, Y and Z together ndash and obviously hindsight is a great thing ndash they might have thought that something was going on.But what about after the barbed wire went down in those first few weeks and the workmen moved into Friedrichstrase to erect the infrastructure at Checkpoint Charlie ndash itrsquos tempting to wonderthe the Allies could have simply pulled down the wire and prevented nearly  years of entombment for Berliners.ldquoI thinktheyrsquod gone straight in and bulldozed the barbed wire down, obviously they would have been taking a massive risk, but the East Germans had discussed that and planned for that, he says. ldquoThey were almost under orders from the Soviets not to match fire with fire and a lot of the East German guards had rles and machines guns that didnrsquot have any bullets in them. Some of them said to the Americans lsquoyou do realise we donrsquot have any bullets  why donrsquot you just pull it down  wersquore not going to stop yoursquo.So in that sense, was that moment when the barbed wire first went down a missed opportunity to prevent the construction of the Berlin Wall  ldquoYes, says Iain, ldquobut yoursquove got to remember that, first, they built the barriers inside their own territory, they werenrsquot stupid, it was a couple of hundred yards inside the Russian zone. President Kennedy had also taken a lot of advice from the doves and the hawks in the White House on the question lsquoshall we knock it down rsquo and what they come down to realise was that as long as theyrsquore not violating the Alliesrsquo right of free access, then there was no basis to knock the barriers down. And Kennedy is famous for saying lsquoa wall is a hell of a lot better than a warrsquo.ldquoHe also had in his mind: what will be their next step ndash theyrsquove done this, perhaps they would go to war over Berlin. And militarily , the US couldnrsquot do anything about it because Berlin is  miles inside the Eastern zone and itrsquos surrounded by around  tanks and half a million Russian troops. So what are we going to do Instead, the Allies waited and watched as the East Germans built grandiose buildings on their side of Checkpoint Charlie. ldquoIf they could, says Iain, ldquothe East Germans would have had the whole of Berlin but that was never going to happen so the next best thing is to say lsquoyou are crossing into a major European country and we take ourselves seriously and wersquore going to spend millions and millions on this state of the art border crossingrsquo when they didnrsquot really need to. Itrsquos your typical Stalinist Communist approach to telling you yoursquore entering a very important place. And it was the exact opposite for the Allies. For them it was a very simplistic cabin just to emphasise to you guys across there that we donrsquot recognise this.By the s, however, behind the grand watchtowers, entropy was beginning to set into the East German state and their Soviet backers. In some of the Eastern Soviet states, democratic protests were growing the economics of the Soviet Union were also looking dodgy and the new guard, led by Mikhail Gorbachev, realised that they could not keep up with the West without being bankrupt the Chernobyl disaster had also cost billions to fix. The new Soviet leadership realised that the writing was on the wall, including the Berlin Wall, and chose not to push back when the pressure started to grow on the ground.Famously, it was on the night of November , , that the wall finally fell and Checkpoint Charlie was one of the epicentres of the peace and celebrations as it had been one of the epicentres of the conflict and Cold War. At least  people crowded round the checkpoint and the side streets near it making it impossible for vehicles to get through. At first, the guards didnrsquot know how to react but as people started to climb on the wall, some of the guards helped them up. Then just after midnight, the dam burst.But, as always happens with history, that moment is not as clear-cut as it looks at first. In some ways the conflict continued, with the Western Allies arguing over whether Germany should be reunited. The fall of the wall also did not lead to the dramatic transformation of East Berlin that many hoped for. The migrations from east Germany to west Germany continue to this day because the standard of living is still much better in the West in. terms of wages and job opportunities . And perhaps most interesting of all: there are some Germans who miss aspects of East Germany. ldquoThe education was really good, healthcare was great, says Iain, ldquobut ultimately there was no political freedom andyou donrsquot have that, you donrsquot have anything.And at Checkpoint Charlie itself, there is a debate about how its past should be remembered. Thirty years on from the day the checkpoint was dismantled on June , , the cityrsquos leaders have unveiled a plan to redevelop the site and build apartments and a new cold war museum, but some believe there should be much more open space where people can gather and debate and reflect. Others, including Iain MacGregor think there are better ways to remember the story of Checkpoint Charlie, which is to walk a few hundred yards to the column of copper that stands on Zimmerstrase. The words on it read: Peter Fechter, -.Checkpoint Charlie: The Cold War, the Berlin Wall and The Most Dangerous Place on Earth by Iain MacGregor is out now.

title: joanna-blythman-local-shops-bouncing-back-supermarkets-stumble-face-coronavirus
story: Irsquove never met a soul who found supermarket shopping joyous. The prevalent view was that it was dull, predictable, anonymous, but it got the job done. Pos-covid, shopping with the multiples feels stressful, weird, even frightening. Thatrsquos why people are making fewer supermarket shopping trips. They have become an ordeal.And here, in a welcome reversal of fortunes, small shops are coming up trumps, as the recent poll of retail experts conducted by the Grocer Magazine shows. When asked the question ldquoWhich sector stands to benefit most from changing shopper behaviour , convenience shops came romping through at .% with supermarkets and discounterstrailing behind on .% and .% respectively.This is a massive reversal in fortunes. Since the s, small food shops have struggled just to stay in business alongside supermarkets, let alone increase their sales.Drill down into that "convenience" shopping category, and a distinctly promising pattern emerges. New figures from Barclaycard show that "specialist" food and drink stores ndash thats greengrocers, convenience stores, butchers, fishmongers, bakeries, whole food shops, and off-licences ndash soared almost % in April, despite overall consumer spending tanking by .% as a result of social distancing and lockdown.The research found that over halfof us now value these traditional outlets more because of the pandemic. Whatrsquos more, we intend to spend more with these shops when restrictions are lted, including at butchers , and farmersrsquo markets .So, a small silver lining to covid-: small food outlets are no longer a residual shopping category. On the contrary, they have become essential to their local communities, a flash of hope on depressed high streets. How come  Many people have never got over the initial shock of being unable to set up a supermarket home delivery slot, and our large food retailers have lost customer loyalty as a result. Supermarkets are still struggling to keep up with the demand. Meanwhile small food concerns have set up delivery services and gained customers who didnrsquot use them or even know they existed before.This new customer base for independent food outlets appreciates the more personal service and less frantic shopping experience they offer. Those who do their shopping in person have appreciated the micro-conversations. ldquoHow are you today  ldquoIs your son feeling better  Little human interactions like this do so much to lt our spirits. For those who live alone, local shops might be the only opportunity to speak to a real human being. And that matters so much for our mental health. For many elderly people who dread the very thought of online ordering, the ability to place an order by phone has been a huge relief.Local food businesses have certainly tapped into the sense of community we have craved amid the anxiety of the pandemic. But a cynic would say that once we get back to normal, when le gets busier, most people will revert to supermarket-centric shopping. Will they  The psychological impact of months of lockdown may leave us less inclined to spend time in busy enclosed spaces like shopping malls and supermarkets. Irsquove heard many people saying that they feel safer and happier visiting local shops than the supermarket. Retail analyst James Child believes that that more of us may even be willing to pay a little more to support local stores. ldquoI believe this trend will continue in a post-Covid- UK.Ultimately, when security concerns wane, it wonrsquot be just the shopping experience that matters. Our satisfaction with the food on sale will be pivotal. Big supermarkets typically stock around , dferent lines, but like a subscription to junk TV, itrsquos a quantitative not a qualitative choice. By the time we finally emerge from lockdown, using small local food shops may be a shopping habit that many more of us choose to sustain. Once people have had a taste of what independents can offer it tends to leave them hungry for more.

title: nicola-sturgeon-asks-people-wait-a-couple-weeks-beer-gardens-re-open
story: Yesterday, the First Minister said beer gardens could be ldquohotspots for the spread of Covid- and therefore will not be allowed to re-open until more investigations into the risk of the disease being transmitted.Camleys Cartoon: Pubs to remain closed.At her daily media briefing, Ms Sturgeon indicated they may remain closed for "a couple of weeks" longer due to emerging evidence about how Covid- transmits between people.ANALYSIS: Is Scotlands slow and steady exit already working Places like gyms and noisy pubs, and also participation in activities like choir singing, could have a greater risk of infection because people breathe dferently, she warned.She added: "Even outdoors,you are in a noisy environment, maybe theres music playing. If people are having alcohol, maybe theyre shouting more than normal."Further investigation is ongoing about more "protective steps" which could be taken, she said."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "What does Phase  actually mean for you ","description": "What does Phase  actually mean for you ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PfNuIVL poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PfNuIVL.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The First Minister added: "I very much hope to see people able to have a pint - or some of us would prefer a glass of wine or a gin and tonic - in a beer garden before too long."But I want to make sure thats safe."If a couple more weeks before we have the ability to have a drink in a beer garden means we can keep this virus really suppressed at a low level, and maybe get our schools back much closer to normal in August, I think most people would think that is a good balance to try to strike.":Face coverings dont make you invincible amid warning over Boxing Day sales scenes as shops re-openJason Leitch, Scotlands national clinical director, added that people would meet in a "less controlled way" in beer gardens than they do at permitted family gatherings outdoors.He said: "I think it will come before indoors."But I think we need a little bit more time, a little bit more data and a little bit more advice before we can reassure the First Minister and the Cabinet that we can safely take this step."

title: snp-politician-labels-scottish-government-blended-learning-plans-absolutely-unacceptable
story: Alex Neil, a former SNP health secretary, accused councils of refusing to try and overcome a lack of teaching space as a barrier for pupils ing to school full time.The Scottish Government has told councils to draw up plans to allow children toto classrooms part-time from August , with social distancing rules, with the rest of the time learning remotely at home.But in recent days, Nicola Sturgeon has appeared to soften her stance on whether the blended learning models will in fact be rolled out when schools re-open their doors amid speculation the two-metre rule could be relaxedthe virus continues to be suppressed.Mr Neil criticised Stephen McCabe, the children and young people spokesperson for the umbrella organisation for Scottish councils, Cosla ndash accusing local authorities of failing to do all they can to increase the time pupils physically spend in schools.Speaking at Holyroodrsquos education committee, Mr Neil said: ldquoIrsquom a grandfather and my grandchildren have just been told theyrsquore going to get, from August , one and half days a week in school for the indefinite future.ldquoI personally and their parents regard that as absolutely unacceptable ndash that is not good quality education, itrsquos not blending education, itrsquos bleeding education. Surely we can do far better than that for our children.:Jason Leitch: Virus prevalence could inform future decision on reducing two-metre ruleMr McCabe, who is also the co-chairman of the Scottish Governmentrsquos education recovery group, admitted that the blended learning model ldquois second best.He added: ldquoThe reality is that we are being advised by the government, by the scientists that at this point in time, children can onlyto school in August on the basis of a two-metre social distancing. Itrsquos impossible for us to provide full time education in that constraint.But Mr Neil questioned why councils cannot ldquotake a leaf out of the NHSrsquos book after the health service took on more staff and saw an emergency facility set up in case it was needed.He said: ldquoWhat they did was they requisitioned the buildings they needed, they recruited the additional staff they needed.ldquoI agree that has to be paid for by the Scottish Government butyou listen to what the paediatricians are saying ndash the cost of getting your children back to school five days a week in terms of their mental health, their physical health, their education, our future economic prospects ndash all of that is dependent on that happening.He added: ldquoDo you not think the attitude should be, let us not take capacity as a constraint but actually address the capacity issues to make sure we give our children as full time.ldquoWe are looking at the moment asScotland is potentially going to be the only one of the four nations in the UK not planning for or at least trying to get a full timeto school in August. Thatrsquos not good enough.ldquoCan we not apply a bit of imagination and create homework hubs for example ndash with the IT equipment to make sure every child has access to what they need to do. This is not getting it right for most children.ldquoI think yoursquove just taken the capacity constraints and decided to work to those and not actually try to overcome them.:Nicola Sturgeon told to stop dithering on schools plan as blended learning could be scrappedBut Mr McCabe disputed the claims, insisting councils and schools are doing all they can to make the proposals work.He said: ldquoThere are around , schools in Scotland. To imagine that we could replicate , schools is just fantasy.ldquoMoney is not the only issue. If the Scottish Government offered councils a blank cheque and said, it doesnrsquot matter what it costs, go out there and double the school estate, get every child back to school full time with face-to-face learning in August, based on two-metre social distancing, we couldnrsquot do it.Scottish Conservative education spokesperson, Jamie Greene, said: ldquoThis is a serious intervention from a former SNP cabinet secretary, who is now saying publicly what many SNP MSPs are thinking privately.ldquoCurrent plans for part-time learning are unworkable and potentially a disaster for children.He added: ldquoAt least Alex Neil has the guts to tell Nicola Sturgeon and his front bench ministers some dficult truths about their lack of ambition and incompetence, adding his name to a growing list of SNP advisers and politicians expressing anger at this shambolic handling of schools.ldquoThe Holyrood committee also learned today of more confusion, with councils admitting that their one and only plan is to only offer a maximum of  per cent attendance in class, in direct contradiction to the First Minister who said that was the contingency plan. Councils are saying one thing, ministers are saying another.ldquoAll the while parents are getting angrier at John Swinney and the SNPrsquos intransigent attitude and complete lack of leadership over such an important issue.

title: scottish-college-staff-demand-four-day-week-1-100-pay-rise-new-normal-proposals
story: Proposals put forward by Unison in collaboration with the GMB and Unite the Union Scotland, seen by The Herald, include payments for home working to be handed over to staff, backdated to include the lockdown and a pound, flat rate increase on all salary points from September .The demands come as newly-qualied teachers have written to the Scottish Government to offer their services to help schools re-opening as an SNP former minister has labelled the plans ldquoabsolutely unacceptable.Scotlandrsquos colleges are facing losing millions of pounds in revenue during the Covid- pandemic ndash but union bosses insist the new arrangements take into account realistic living costs and a fair deal in adapting to le as the country emerges from the crisis, with social distancing still likely to be in place.Union leaders want a four-day working week ldquoat no loss of earnings, based on a -hour week. There are also calls for an ldquourgent joint working group to be set up to agree funding to support the mental health and wellbeing of staff ndash as well as green travel schemes for workers to take advantage of loans to buy bicycles.:SNP politician labels Scottish Government blended learning plans absolutely unacceptableThe unions have also proposed ldquolevelling of annual leave entitlement for all colleges to  days and a payment of a pound allowance to all first aiders.But one of the biggest asks in the plans is a pound, salary increase to take affect by September.In , unions struck a deal for a two-and-a-half year pay agreement with Colleges Scotlandrsquos employers association ndash which saw pay rise by at least pound, over the -month period.Chris Greenshields, branch secretary of the Unison Scotland further education branch, said: "Unison is keen to secure a fair cash pay settlement for professional and support staff in colleges after years of suppression of wages.ldquoAdditionally though we are keen to be innovative and to change working practices to reflect new ways of viewing work-le balance, productivity, green travel to work schemes.ldquoWe hope that the further education employers will engage us in serious discussions on implementing these measures for introduction in the new academic year. This approach will benefit employers, staff, students and wider society."But colleges are not exempt from the Covid- crisis and are facing a stark economic outlook, alongside many of Scotlands other sectors.Karen Watt, from the Scottish Funding Council, has warned that ldquothere is no doubt that Covid- presents a unique and signicant external shock to further and higher education in Scotland.:Coronavirus: Scottish universities could have to curtail research ambitions amid funding reviewShe added: ldquoWe estimate that there will be losses in the region of pound million in the current academic year, but the losses will be much greater in the next year.ldquoColleges and universities will also play a vital role in helping Scotland to recover from the current situation.College staff in Scotland are able toto work in phase two of the Scottish Governments routemap in easing the coronavirus lockdown ndash with students allowed toin phase three as things stand, likely to be in three weeks time at the earliest.The body representing Scotlands colleges has warned that the institutions face uncertain financial futures ndash but confirmed the union proposals were being examined.Shona Struthers, chief executive of Colleges Scotland, said: ldquoWe welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos announcement that we can move to phase two of the route map through the Covid- crisis, which means that appropriate college staff can nowto campuses to make preparations for the new academic year and the reopening of college buildings for students in phase three.ldquoA college sector working group, including trade union representatives, has been exploring in recent weeks how to ensure the safe reopening of campuses so that staff and students cansafely whilst adhering to Scottish Government and Public Health Scotland guidelines and social distancing measures."She added: ldquoThe college sector is facing signicant financial pressures which are being exacerbated by the Covid- pandemic. "The established forum to discuss trade unionsrsquo pay, terms and conditions claims is the National Joint Negotiating Committee and we will discuss these issues ndash which have only recently been submitted ndash through this mechanism.ldquoWhilst the college sector has remained open virtually with online learning continuing throughout the lockdown period, we are looking forward to seeing staff ndash and later students ndashto campuses across Scotland.The University and College Unionhas warned that safety advice for university staff has not been published despite the Scottish Government telling workers they canfrom Monday.The union has criticised the Scottish Government for making the announcement without signing off on advice for reopening campuses, and said the "hugely disappointing" decision which will leave staff worried.UCU Scotland official Mary Senior said it would be "foolhardy" for staff towithout tailored guidance, despite the Governments route map out of lockdown stating college and university workers canto make essential preparations for the planned resumption of "blended" study ahead of phase three.Ms Senior said the move was "out of step with every other sector" and contradicted promises that the guidance would be published before staff could .She added: "University staff have been working tirelessly since the beginning of this crisis to move and deliver teaching and support for students online."UCU has been working with the Scottish Government to develop critical guidance to allow universities to move back to campus-based teaching when the time is right and it is safe for staff and students."It is hugely disappointing, and will be worrying for staff, to see the First Minister announce that staff canto university buildings before the guidance we and others have been working so hard to produce is even published.""In the absence of the guidance, and the opportunity for everyone to be reassured that the guidance, along with a risk assessment-based approach is met and adhered to, it would be foolhardy for universities to be demanding staffto workplaces."A Scottish Government spokeswoman said: "The safety and wellbeing of students and staff is our overriding priority as universities plan for the next academic year."As the Higher and Further Education Minister has made clear, it is important to emphasise that we expect only a small number of people to be on campus for essential preparations for re-opening in phase three, and remote working remains the default position for those who can."Guidance is due to be published next week and we continue to work closely with universities, student bodies and university staff representatives on plans for a phasedto campus."

title: 1975-magazine-started-arbroath-link-us-declaration
story: But experts now believe they have traced the source of the legend that the Declaration of Arbroath directly inspired the American Declaration of Independence and conclude the myth was actually inspired by a s magazine.The story about the influence of the  Declaration of Arbroath influencing Americarsquos founding fathers in drawing up their  document is described as ldquoone of Scottish historyrsquos most enduring myths.It was even enshrined into American law. In  Republican Senator Trent Lott successfully introduced a motion in Congress that the annual anniversary of the Declaration of Abroath, April , should become National Tartan Day in the US, a celebration of Scottish heritage in America.Mr Lott suggested that ldquoby honouring April , Americans will annually celebrate the true beginning of the quest for liberty and freedom ndash Arbroath and the declaration for liberty.He was referring to the belief the American Declaration of Independence was directly inspired by the Declaration of Arbroath, written by Scottish barons to Pope John XXII, asserting the ancient independence of the Kingdom of Scotland and denouncing English attempts to subjugate it.But a number of scholars have since devoted extensive time to disproving this theory. Among them was American cultural geographer Professor Euan Hague, who examined the sources used by the compilers of the Declaration of Independence, as well as records of their personal libraries, and concluded ldquothe Declaration of Arbroath is conspicuous only by its total absence.Now, Historic Environment Scotland [HES] researcher Dr Laura Harrison claims to have traced the source of the myth to a s magazine. In an HES blog, she said yesterday: ldquoWe have a responsibility to inform our members and visitors about the past with the most accurate and up-to-date information we can.ldquoOne way we approach this is via exploring myth-building, rather than just myth-busting. We identy where an inaccurate myth exists, but we explore how it came to be believed.ldquoOne example of this is a supposed connection between the Declaration of Arbroath and the American Declaration of Independence.ldquoSo where does the myth come from  It appears to be relatively new. The earliest mention I have found is from , when it is mentioned in an American Scottish Clan Societyrsquos members magazine.ldquoSince then it has been mentioned in a number of places on both sides of the Atlantic, from Westminster to an American late-night television show Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson.ldquoItrsquos in popular history books and in the Resolution for Tartan Day. Ms Harrison said the myth ldquomay come down to an issue of naming.She said: ldquoFrom about  until relatively recently the Declaration of Arbroath was often called the Scottish Declaration of Independence. Thus, the two perhaps became conflated in peoplersquos minds. Of course, as with all myths, there is an element of truth.ldquoThe Declaration of Arbroath was one of a number of medieval documents that helped contribute to ideas of proto-democracy. But we can safely say Thomas Jefferson did not have a picture of it hanging in his study as he drafted the Declaration of Independence.Applying what she calls ldquosome quickfire myth-busting to some other common historical myths and stories, Ms Harrison also targets whether a spider really did inspire Robert The Bruce to continue his fight for the Scottish crown. She claims the story was popularised ndash and possibly made up ndash by Sir Walter Scott in his Tales Of A Grandfather.She also dismisses the idea there were mer-people between the Hebrides and the Mainland.The Blue Men Of Minch were said to swim the stretch of water looking for sailors to drown, which helped explain the losses of le in dangerous stretches of water. Ms Harrison also questions whether the Picts painted themselves blue before going into battle.

title: scottish-water-taps-sources-renewable-energy-rises
